(24.5)\u00a0</td><td>16.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.88\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[21.75\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08]\u00a0</td><td>1.20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>z</em> (23.6)\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.49\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>y</em> (22.2)\u00a0</td><td>16.08\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008\u00a0</td><td>15.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.007\u00a0</td><td>16.02\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.007\u00a0</td><td>17.57\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.016\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>J</em> (21.4)\u00a0</td><td>15.92\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.012\u00a0</td><td>[19.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Ks</em> (20.1)\u00a0</td><td>15.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.009\u00a0</td><td>16.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.027\u00a0</td><td>[17.33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry is determined by using information from multiple filters (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span>3). The units are in arcsec and the sign convention is positive from E to W (<em>x</em>-axis) and from S to N (<em>y</em>-axis). The ICRS position of image A in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 catalogue is (J2000.0) 11:34:40.588\u201321:03:23.06. Magnitudes are in the AB (<em>grizy</em>) and Vega (<em>YJKs</em>) systems, and are corrected for Galactic extinction following Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span>2011). The 1\u03c3 limiting magnitudes are computed in 2\u2009arcsec-radius blank sky apertures around the system. The errors on magnitudes are those from MCMC, with the minimum uncertainty boosted to 0.005 mag, and do not include zero-point or PSF uncertainties. The magnitudes of G and GX (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span>5) should be considered unreliable, as in order for the fit to converge, the effective radius was fixed to &lt;1\u00a0pixel.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry is determined by using information from multiple filters (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span>3). The units are in arcsec and the sign convention is positive from E to W (<em>x</em>-axis) and from S to N (<em>y</em>-axis). The ICRS position of image A in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 catalogue is (J2000.0) 11:34:40.588\u201321:03:23.06. Magnitudes are in the AB (<em>grizy</em>) and Vega (<em>YJKs</em>) systems, and are corrected for Galactic extinction following Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span>2011). The 1\u03c3 limiting magnitudes are computed in 2\u2009arcsec-radius blank sky apertures around the system. The errors on magnitudes are those from MCMC, with the minimum uncertainty boosted to 0.005 mag, and do not include zero-point or PSF uncertainties. The magnitudes of G and GX (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span>5) should be considered unreliable, as in order for the fit to converge, the effective radius was fixed to &lt;1\u00a0pixel.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>243.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>30.5\u00a0</td><td>6.8\u00a0</td><td>54.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>384.1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>196.6\u00a0</td><td>43.9\u00a0</td><td>353.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>242.1\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>24.7\u00a0</td><td>6.3\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>382.6\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>159.0\u00a0</td><td>40.3\u00a0</td><td>281.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>233.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>33.9\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>44.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>363.4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>225.9\u00a0</td><td>49.3\u00a0</td><td>263.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf7\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here <em>z</em> is the lens redshift, \u03c3 is the lens velocity dispersion, <em>e</em> and \u03b3 are the lens ellipticity and shear, respectively, and \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> and \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub> are their orientations (W of N). \">Journals Career Network</a>\r\n                \r\n            </li>\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-1\" id=\"site-menu-item-1493360\">\r\n                <a class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    A search for gravitationally lensed quasars and quasar pairs in Pan-STARRS1: spectroscopy and sources of shear in the diamond 2M1134\u22122103\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">Cristian E Rusu</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    Cristian E Rusu\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-cor1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"cor1\" class=\"aff\">Subaru Telescope, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan, 650\u00a0N Aohoku Pl, Hilo, HI 96720, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-author-correspondence\">\r\n $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Eccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nEccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f486%2f4%2f4987%2f5484879\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n       <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515681 id=\"135515681\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present results of a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in Pan-STARRS1. Our final sample of candidates comprises of 91 systems, not including 25 rediscovered lensed quasars and quasar pairs. In the absence of spectroscopy to verify the lensing nature of the candidates, the main sources of contaminants are likely to be quasar pairs, which we consider to be a byproduct of our work, and a smaller number of quasar + star associations. Among the independently discovered quads is 2M1134\u22122103, for which we obtained spectroscopy for the first time, finding a redshift of 2.77 for the quasar. There is evidence for microlensing in at least one image. We perform detailed mass modelling of this system using archival imaging data, and find that the unusually large shear responsible for the diamond-like configuration can be attributed mainly to a faint companion \u223c4\u2009arcsec away, and to a galaxy group/cluster \u223c30\u2009arcsec away. We also set limits of <em>z</em> \u223c 0.5\u20131.5 on the redshift of the lensing galaxy, based on its brightness, the image separation of the lensed images, and an analysis of the observed photometric flux ratios.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: 2M1134\u22122103&quot;\">quasars: individual: 2M1134\u22122103</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515683 id=\"135515683\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To date, \u223c60 quadruple (quad) and \u223c200 double gravitationally lensed quasars have been discovered.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> Their value as probes of cosmology and astrophysics has been explored observationally for the past four decades (see e.g. reviews by Claeskens\u00a0&amp; Surdej <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Treu\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), yet their number is still a limiting factor for many focused studies (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We are currently in a post-Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) era when the large ongoing imaging surveys such as the Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System (Pan-STARRS1, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>; Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the Dark Energy Survey (Flaugher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and the Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru Strategic Program (Aihara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) do not (yet) have a spectroscopic counterpart, making it difficult to identify lensed quasars. As a result, contemporary dedicated searches for lensed quasars rely on selecting their candidates by applying machine learning techniques such as artificial neural networks (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) or Gaussian mixture models (e.g. Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Williams, Agnello\u00a0&amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) to multifilter photometric catalogues in conjunction with pixel-by-pixel pattern recognition; by looking for flux and position offsets between these surveys and <em>Gaia</em> (e.g. Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Agnello\u00a0&amp; Spiniello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), including capitalizing on the superior <em>Gaia</em> resolution to resolve blended sources (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018c</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Delchambre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and combining multiple such methods (e.g. Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>); by assessing the plausibility of valid lensing configurations on automatically detected sources (e.g. Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>); and/or by complementing these with variability information (e.g. Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Kostrzewa-Rutkowska et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Encouraged by the serendipitous discovery by Berghea et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) of the first quad from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>, PSOJ0147, we have begun a systematic search for lensed quasars in this survey, by cross-correlating sources with the parent active galactic nucleus (AGN) catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). As the first <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data were released in 2016 December, mining it for lensed quasars has only recently begun (e.g. Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), making it likely that other lensed quasars, including bright, large separation quads, are yet to be found. Given the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sky coverage and depth, Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) estimate that <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> contains \u223c2000 lensed quasars, including 300 quads.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recently, Lucey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>) have announced the discovery of a new bright, large-separation quad, 2M1134\u22122103. This was a serendipitous discovery, as part of a search for extended 2MASS (Skrutskie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) sources in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> footprint, to include as targets for the Taipan Galaxy Survey (da Cunha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). As part of our search, we have independently discovered this system. Here, we aim to present a more in-depth modelling of the archival imaging data, looking in particular to identify the cause for the unusually large shear inferred in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>. In addition, we present for the first time spectroscopic data for this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The structure of this paper is as follows: in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> we describe our search technique and a new sample of lensed quasars and quasar pair candidates. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> we describe our analysis of the archival imaging data of 2M1134\u22122103, and in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> our newly acquired spectroscopic data. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> we present our mass modelling of 2M1134\u22122103, and provide plausible explanations for the unusually large shear. We conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. Where necessary, we use a flat cosmology with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda =0.74$|</span> and <em>h</em>\u00a0= 0.72.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515688 id=\"135515688\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 A SEARCH FOR GRAVITATIONALLY LENSED QUASARS IN <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a></h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515689 id=\"135515689\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Selection based on catalogue cuts and visual inspection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> is a wide-field imaging system with a 1.8\u00a0m telescope and 7.7\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> field of view, located on the summit of Haleakala in the Hawaiian island of Maui. The 1.4 Gpixel camera consists of 60 CCDs with pixel size of 0.256 arcsec (Onaka\u00a0&amp; al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Tonry\u00a0&amp; Onaka <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The first <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data release includes both images and a photometry catalogue (Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> uses five SDSS-like filters (<em>g</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>r</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>i</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>z</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>y</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>). The largest survey <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> performs is the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3 \\pi$|</span> survey, covering the entire sky north of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-30\\deg$|</span> declination.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As we did for PSOJ0147, we start our search with the AGN candidates catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), based on two mid-infrared colours measured with the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We cross-correlate this catalogue with the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> (Flewelling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) using a 3\u2009arcsec radius cone search and keep 79\u2009951 candidates which have at least two counterparts (step <em>i</em>). Next, we remove candidates within 15 deg of the galactic plane, resulting in 64\u2009055 remaining sources (<em>ii</em>). We then impose a faint magnitude cut of <em>i</em>\u00a0= 19.5 on the closest counterpart, in order to eliminate spurious candidates. This results in 25\u2009493 sources remaining (<em>iii</em>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> Finally, we impose that the two brightest sources in each system should be similar in colour, removing the ones with <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> differences larger than 1.5 mag and <em>i</em> \u2212 <em>y</em> differences larger than 1.0 mag (<em>iv</em>). The final sample contains 18\u2009015 candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We chose these cuts in order to recover most of the known lenses at the intersection of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> and the Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) catalogue, while resulting in a number of candidates small enough to allow visual inspection. From an all-sky catalogue of \u223c260 known lenses (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), which we matched with the Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) catalogue to insure a match within 10\u2009arcsec, we found 45 lenses for which their Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) catalogue counterparts have at least two detections in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> within 3\u2009arcsec (corresponding to step <em>i</em>). These are further reduced to 44 (step <em>ii</em>), 32 (<em>iii</em>), and 30 lenses (<em>iv</em>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> In addition to the cross-match with the known catalogue of lensed quasars, we also looked for previously known non-lens systems, by cross-matching the coordinates of our candidates with the list of known sources from the SIMBAD Astronomical Data base<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> and the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Data base.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We downloaded 30\u00a0\u00d7 30\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup> postage stamp colour JPEG images of the candidates using the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> cut-out service,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> which were then inspected visually by three of the authors (CTB, ES, and GJN). Pairs with separation \u2272a few arcsec between components (consistent with strong lensing by galaxies) and similar colours, triplets with a redder inner component, as well as quads with configurations consistent with canonical lensing configurations were kept. Finally, another three authors (CER, AM, and GCFC) graded the remaining sample of 448 candidates. As is customary in the lens search community, they used the following grading system: 0: unlikely to be a lens; 1: possibly a lens candidate (satisfies only some criteria to be a lens); 2: probably a lens candidate (satisfies most criteria to be a lens); 3: almost certainly a lens (there is almost no doubt that this is a lens). We find 312 systems with an average grade \u22651, and discard the rest.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of the 312 candidates, we recover a total of 15 known lenses. Of these, 6 are quads: PS\u00a0J0147+4630 (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), 2M 1134\u22122103 (Lucey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1433+6007 (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>), GraL\u00a0J1537\u22123010 (Delchambre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), PS\u00a0J1606\u22122333 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and PS\u00a0J1721+8842 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and 9 are doubles: DES\u00a0J0245\u22120556 (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), PS\u00a0J0259\u22122338 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), HE 1104\u22121805 (Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), J1206\u22122543 (Lemon et\u00a0al. in preparation), SDSS\u00a0J1206+4332 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1320+1644 (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), ULAS\u00a0J1405+0959 (Jackson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1515+1511 (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and J2212+3144 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This means that at the grading stage we miss the cluster quad SDSS\u00a0J1004+4112 (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). In addition, at the initial visual inspection stage to produce the list for grading we miss the quad PG1115+080 (Weymann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) and 15 doubles: PS\u00a0J0028+0631 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), J0102+2445 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), Q0142\u2013100 (Surdej et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>), PS\u00a0J0949+4208 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1001+5027 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1313+5151 (Ofek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1349+1227 (Kayo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1442+4055 (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), ULAS\u00a0J1527+0141 (Jackson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), PS\u00a0J2124+1632 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), another double from Ostrovski et\u00a0al. in preparation and four more doubles from Lemon et\u00a0al. in preparation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our cross-match with known lenses shows that we are more efficient at recovering quads than doubles, which is to be expected, because typical quad configurations are easier to identify visually. We are also biased against large-separation lenses, due to our requirement to have at least two components within 3\u2009arcsec. Since at the visual selection stage we miss 17/32 of the known lenses included in our cut-outs, we expect the completeness of our sample of candidates, defined as the ratio of the number of gravitational lenses in the final sample to the true number of lenses in the cut-outs, to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\lesssim } 50{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Most of these are missed at the initial visual inspection stage. This can be attributed to two factors: first, most of the missed systems are doubles with only two clearly visible components in the cut-outs, and with noticeable colour differences between the components. On the other hand, the authors who have inspected the 18\u2009015 candidates have no formal experience with gravitational lenses. When the authors with formal experience graded 11/17 missed lenses, 9 of these received an average grade \u22651.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that other known quads with bright lensing galaxies, such as 2M1310\u22121714 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>), are not included in our sample because the lens light contaminates the infrared colours that the Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) AGN catalogue is based on. Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) note that the chance of misclassifying stars in the AGN catalogue is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\le 0.041{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, so we expect that the main contaminants to our list of candidates, after visual examination, will be quasar + star pairs as well as quasar pairs, as either physically associated binary quasars or projected chance alignments. Indeed, 93 of our candidates, the great majority of those with spectroscopic results in the literature, consist of at least one AGN.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that we have typically given a grade of 1 to candidates consisting of object pairs without signs of additional emission, as long as the separation was not too large. This is for two reasons: first, the lensing galaxy may be too faint to detect, which is consistent with the large fraction of known doubles we miss. This fraction would undoubtedly be even higher if we chose to exclude these pairs. Second, because rather than focusing on producing the purest lensed quasar sample, we prefer to include in our sample binary quasars and quasar pairs, which are of interest to the AGN community, for example for studies of quasar triggering (e.g. Hopkins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), and of the small-scale quasar\u2013quasar correlation function (e.g. Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kayo\u00a0&amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515698 id=\"135515698\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Removal of quasar\u2013star pairs using <em>Gaia</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The recent availability of the <em>Gaia</em> mission (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and in particular of its second data release catalogue (DR2; Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>), has resulted in wide application in the latest searches for lensed quasars, as demonstrated by the multitude of recent studies enumerated in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>. Here, we capitalize on the astrometric quantities included in this catalogue in order to further prune our list of candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em> DR2 includes \u223c1.7 billion sources over the whole sky, with a limiting magnitude of <em>G</em> \u223c 21 (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). With a full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of \u22480.1\u2009arcsec (Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), <em>Gaia</em> is effective at deblending close pairs and clusters of objects, down to 0.4\u2009arcsec in DR2 (Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Multi-epoch photometry has enabled the measurement of proper motions and parallaxes for \u223c360 million sources, and the Astrometric Excess Noise (AEN; Koposov, Belokurov\u00a0&amp; Torrealba <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) provides a means of separating compact galaxies from point sources. Colour information (<em>Rp</em> \u2212 <em>Bp</em>) is also available for \u223c1.4 billion sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have cross-matched our candidates with the <em>Gaia</em> DR2 catalogue, in order to identify the counterparts of both <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sources in each candidate (up to four sources, in case of quads). Of the 312 candidates, 307 have detections in <em>Gaia</em>, 291 of these have measured parallaxes and proper motions, and 283 have measured colours. Of their companions (i.e. the secondary component in the pair of each system, or the brightest secondary component in case of quads), the corresponding numbers are 291, 276, and 260.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the proper motion as a classifier, in the form of the proper motion significance defined by Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sqrt{(\\mathrm{ pm}_\\mathrm{ra}/\\sigma _{\\mathrm{ pm}_\\mathrm{ra}})^2+\\mathrm{ pm}_\\mathrm{dec}/\\sigma _{\\mathrm{ pm}\\mathrm{ }_\\mathrm{dec}})^2}$|\u2060</span>, which includes both celestial coordinates, and where \u03c3 stands for the measured uncertainty. We adopt a limiting upper value of 5, which recovers <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }95{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of known lensed quasar images (see fig.\u00a01 in Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). For the parallax \u03d6, we use \u03d6/\u03c3<sub>\u03d6</sub>\u00a0\u2264\u00a04, corresponding to a 4\u03c3 limit, since the distribution of measured parallaxes is well approximated by a Gaussian (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). Finally, we use AEN\u00a0\u2264\u00a04, corresponding to the limit which separates best between lensed quasar images and galaxies, and recovers <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }90{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of the former (see fig.\u00a02 in Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our final classification of the 312 candidates is: 91 surviving candidates yet unconfirmed (1 grade A, 4 grade B, and 86 grade C), 25 confirmed systems (6 quads, 9 doubles,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">9</a></sup> 10 quasar pairs), and 196 rejected candidates. We present our final sample of 91 gravitationally lensed quasar and quasar pair candidates in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, together with our comments based on visual inspection and <em>Gaia</em> measurements. In Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a> we also list the already confirmed candidates, as well as the rejected ones. From these tables it can be seen that the proper motion was the dominant classifier for the overwhelming majority of candidates. Finally, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows that the companions have a similar distribution of <em>Gaia</em> colours with the primary sources, but are typically fainter.</p>                        <a id=\"135515704\" no <em>Gaia</em> data\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here \u03b1 and \u03b4 are the right ascension and declination of the candidates in the International Celestial Reference System. \u2018#Comp\u2019 refers to the number of components, where we use the number of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sources inside 3\u2009arcsec radius, but revise it based on visual inspection, removing spurious sources and counting additional objects which appear to be part of the system. The measured separation (\u2018Sep.\u2019, in arcsec) is that between the lens candidate point sources or, in case of a quad, the maximum separation between any of the point sources, taken from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or revised as described above. The magnitude is given in <em>i</em> band in the AB system for the brightest resolved component. We quote the <span class=\"monospace\">iMeanPSFMag</span> measurements from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) <span class=\"monospace\">MAG_AUTO</span> in case we had to manually add the brightest component of the system, as described above. We also quote the <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitudes for each system, in the order of increasing separation from the WISE source coordinates. Here \u2018p-l\u2019 stands for \u2018point-like\u2019, whereas \u2018AEN\u2019 (astrometric excess noise), \u2018p\u2019 (parallax), and \u2018pm\u2019 (proper motion) are <em>Gaia</em>-based measurements. We list in this table the alphabetic ranking as gravitationally lensed quasars for all systems with an average grade of 1 and above, based on three human graders, as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. We follow the following convention for the alphabetic ranking: A: average grade &gt;2.5; B: average grade &gt;1.5; C: average grade \u22651. SQLS refers to the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). SDSS spectra were searched inside Data Release 14 (Abolfathi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup>a</sup>After the first draft of this work (arXiv:1803.07175v1), this system was independently announced by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) as a candidate. Our <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> modelling of the observed configuration with an SIE+\u03b3 mass profile results in a perfect fit, but the model is underconstrained because the lensing galaxy is not detected.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;
