p-l; only one component has <em>Gaia</em>data, negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>233525+184309\u00a0</td><td>353.85286\u00a0</td><td>18.71912\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>19.31\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>red components; no <em>Gaia</em> data\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here \u03b1 and \u03b4 are the right ascension and declination of the candidates in the International Celestial Reference System. \u2018#Comp\u2019 refers to the number of components, where we use the number of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sources inside 3\u2009arcsec radius, but revise it based on visual inspection, removing spurious sources and counting additional objects which appear to be part of the system. The measured separation (\u2018Sep.\u2019, in arcsec) is that between the lens candidate point sources or, in case of a quad, the maximum separation between any of the point sources, taken from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or revised as described above. The magnitude is given in <em>i</em> band in the AB system for the brightest resolved component. We quote the <span class=\"monospace\">iMeanPSFMag</span> measurements from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) <span class=\"monospace\">MAG_AUTO</span> in case we had to manually add the brightest component of the system, as described above. We also quote the <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitudes for each system, in the order of increasing separation from the WISE source coordinates. Here \u2018p-l\u2019 stands for \u2018point-like\u2019, whereas \u2018AEN\u2019 (astrometric excess noise), \u2018p\u2019 (parallax), and \u2018pm\u2019 (proper motion) are <em>Gaia</em>-based measurements. We list in this table the alphabetic ranking as gravitationally lensed quasars for all systems with an average grade of 1 and above, based on three human graders, as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. We follow the following convention for the alphabetic ranking: A: average grade &gt;2.5; B: average grade &gt;1.5; C: average grade \u22651. SQLS refers to the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). SDSS spectra were searched inside Data Release 14 (Abolfathi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup>a</sup>After the first draft of this work (arXiv:1803.07175v1), this system was independently announced by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) as a candidate. Our <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> modelling of the observed configuration with an SIE+\u03b3 mass profile results in a perfect fit, but the model is underconstrained because the lensing galaxy is not detected.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515705\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515706 id=\"135515706\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Expected sample purity</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the expected completeness, we also wish to estimate the purity of our sample, defined as the ratio of (number of gravitational lenses +quasar pairs)/(total number of sources in the sample). First, we perform a simple exercise where we estimate this number focusing only on the quasar pairs, and comparing the density of sources in a catalogue of point sources, and one of AGN. The idea is to estimate how many of the candidate source companions are expected to be AGN, as opposed to stars. We present the details of the computation in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec7\">A</a>. We arrive at a result of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim } 4{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected purity can be computed more directly using the subsample of candidates for which spectroscopic data are available in the literature. Out of 33 candidates which survive the <em>Gaia</em>-based cut and which can be either confirmed or ruled out based on the literature, 9 are doubles, 10 are quasar pairs, 6 are quads, and 8 are galaxy + other, star + other, or star + QSO (here \u2018other\u2019 stands for non-QSO). For systems with <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020 for all components (the limit at which <em>Gaia</em> is still relatively complete), these numbers are 7, 9, 5, and 5, respectively. This means that for <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020, if we ignore the quads (there is only one quad candidate in our final sample, and these systems are much easier to identify visually, leading to different selection), the purity for quasar pairs is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$9/21\\approx 43{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, and for doubles + quasar pairs it is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16/21\\approx 76{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Of course, care must be taken in interpreting this result, as the spectroscopic selection of these sources compiled from the literature is unknown.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">How can the discrepant results of the two methods be reconciled? This is likely due to the known clustering of quasars, which leads to a significant enhancement of small-separation quasar\u2013quasar pairs over expectations from uniform spatial distribution assumptions and catalogue density comparisons, and it means that the number we computed with that method must be interpreted as a lower limit. The quasar\u2013quasar correlation function is predicted to produce an enhanced by a factor of \u223c100 on small angular scales corresponding to quasar pairs (e.g. Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>, and references therein). For our 91 candidates and confirmed quasar pairs we measure a median separation of 2.4\u2009arcsec, with a standard deviation of 0.53\u2009arcsec (after removing four systems with separation &gt;4.5\u2009arcsec). Kayo\u00a0&amp; Oguri (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) do indeed estimate an increase by a factor of \u223c200 in the number of quasar pairs with separation typical for our candidates (physical scale \u223c20\u00a0kpc), over the random expectation, based on a sample of binary quasars obtained as a byproduct of a search for gravitationally lensed quasars (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). This is more than enough to explain the discrepancy. In fact, multiplying this number with the fraction of AGN to point sources found in our simple exercise suggests a purity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }90{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. This may be an overestimate, as there is a known discrepancy between the large number of predicted binary quasars (e.g. Hopkins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and the smaller number of discovered ones (e.g. Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We adopt as our best estimate of the purity the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }76{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> value measured above for quasar pairs + doubles, although we caution that this estimate might be biased due to the unknown spectroscopic selection, and applies only to <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020. If we remove the magnitude cut, based on the spectroscopic sample, this becomes <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }70{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the following sections, we focus on modelling the imaging and spectroscopic data of 2M1134\u22122103.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515711 id=\"135515711\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 2M1134\u22122103: IMAGING DATA REDUCTION AND MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">2M1134\u22122103 consists of four point-like lensed quasar images and a lensing galaxy (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The lensing galaxy 2M1134\u22122103 can be convincingly identified in the near-infrared imaging (particularly <em>Ks</em>-band) from the VISTA Hemisphere Survey (hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a>; McMahon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, see also Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). While the relative astrometry of the quasar images, measured from VST-ATLAS (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), is reported in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, the VST-ATLAS data are not publicly accessible. Furthermore, the VST-ATLAS data have better seeing (0.72\u2009arcsec) but the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data are deeper. Therefore, we make use of archival <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data in our analysis. The processing of the archival <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data (Flewelling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) is described in Magnier et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), and includes removal of the instrumental signature, image coaddition, as well as photometric and astrometric calibration (Magnier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>). Here, we model the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>,<em>grizy</em> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a>,<em>YJKs</em> images independently of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"135515713\" scrollto-destination=\"135515713\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a02.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=0iLR~dG395eJqDaQEpBxaLknRPFyTuvH4eNMJjLx3XM4XIFbWORHTM6W5gbyiGzmFfd1RM-elAz5X5ucozL6sOTo8Ixo4sYKFms64JYEPnLBVjNj3gVRG~kj2sAAxHp6gx6s0tn~W-uhb7h~pU63LNM3C1QM7-DmqMDnIQ7lJ6I4GRC5D0Jm1DLnNZuGgavwZh1VfyKYIKDLwLpKrmIKcHiVW~18IdE1DO7ALDyXUqrFjJ~JoKdi6bUOZgleTnEaqRc3vV8yPoae2abo1Oehet0ilxkf6Q8sdl62HHS1X83WNLjeAXPBi5v9jDCGpEGUG3HYyyTxm-ZI13CMi1cL8Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper left: Colour composite (VHS-YJKs) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. Lower left: The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with hostlens, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. Right: Colour composite (riz) using PS1 data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515713/stz1142fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515713\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=dKX1sYZgDjDB0QpcTwhX3z0iOI~VPSd0Ye9vAg8pyTKFXxQ5pkx8SBj5sq9jNVi5UOhG1dnnzFL~vLOVdpljFdptNMAh4be4c2dwUs0QjvaS2h3towzUyESnsF5TdJp3dALaH5GmVrYHXCedpzQ-WYizoAJdHQOeDZ0VN88eAkmDHtex9sybRSWQWox2bSM7CqCc0~5XOAkYmqLL67Rb1rRdIt01hG9bOtPA5ivJtF9QWv-NhXNCOFDTFD52toN1UBNRZ0T26SwNBo0rlobzqICOv0~C8XJtjGfraHuxDSn6uWI0Sx1pj3WiCZHtI9z0WL-Kdg98~9uk0Tt-4M6zmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515713&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Upper left:</em> Colour composite (VHS-<em>YJKs</em>) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. <em>Lower left:</em> The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. <em>Right:</em> Colour composite (<em>riz</em>) using <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a02.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=0iLR~dG395eJqDaQEpBxaLknRPFyTuvH4eNMJjLx3XM4XIFbWORHTM6W5gbyiGzmFfd1RM-elAz5X5ucozL6sOTo8Ixo4sYKFms64JYEPnLBVjNj3gVRG~kj2sAAxHp6gx6s0tn~W-uhb7h~pU63LNM3C1QM7-DmqMDnIQ7lJ6I4GRC5D0Jm1DLnNZuGgavwZh1VfyKYIKDLwLpKrmIKcHiVW~18IdE1DO7ALDyXUqrFjJ~JoKdi6bUOZgleTnEaqRc3vV8yPoae2abo1Oehet0ilxkf6Q8sdl62HHS1X83WNLjeAXPBi5v9jDCGpEGUG3HYyyTxm-ZI13CMi1cL8Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper left: Colour composite (VHS-YJKs) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. Lower left: The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with hostlens, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. Right: Colour composite (riz) using PS1 data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515713/stz1142fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515713\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=dKX1sYZgDjDB0QpcTwhX3z0iOI~VPSd0Ye9vAg8pyTKFXxQ5pkx8SBj5sq9jNVi5UOhG1dnnzFL~vLOVdpljFdptNMAh4be4c2dwUs0QjvaS2h3towzUyESnsF5TdJp3dALaH5GmVrYHXCedpzQ-WYizoAJdHQOeDZ0VN88eAkmDHtex9sybRSWQWox2bSM7CqCc0~5XOAkYmqLL67Rb1rRdIt01hG9bOtPA5ivJtF9QWv-NhXNCOFDTFD52toN1UBNRZ0T26SwNBo0rlobzqICOv0~C8XJtjGfraHuxDSn6uWI0Sx1pj3WiCZHtI9z0WL-Kdg98~9uk0Tt-4M6zmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515713&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Upper left:</em> Colour composite (VHS-<em>YJKs</em>) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. <em>Lower left:</em> The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. <em>Right:</em> Colour composite (<em>riz</em>) using <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For our detailed modelling of 2M1134\u22122103 we downloaded from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> archives 180\u00a0\u00d7 180\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup> cut-outs around the system in all available filters, large enough to contain stars to model the PSF and to improve the image orientation. We subtracted the sky background from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> images using <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), and resampled all images with <span class=\"small-caps\">swarp</span> (Bertin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) to a common orientation. We measured final pixel scales with <span class=\"small-caps\">scamp</span> (Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We model the system with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span> (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span> models an arbitrary number of point-like and extended sources using a common point spread function (PSF), either specified by the user from nearby stars, or fitted to the data as a sum of two concentric Moffat (Moffat <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1969</a>) profiles. We find that modelling the quasar images using nearby stars as PSFs results in significant residuals, which could affect the image flux measurements and the characterization of the lensing galaxy. We therefore model the data using an analytical PSF fitted to the data. To remove residuals still remaining at the centres of the three bright quasar images in the <em>rizYJKs</em> bands, we use the PSF reconstruction technique described in Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), with the best-fitting analytical PSF as a starting point. This technique reconstructs the PSF iteratively, on a grid of pixels, under the assumption that the PSF does not vary across the quasar images. The remaining residuals at the location of the quasar images are small, as can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"135515716\" scrollto-destination=\"135515716\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a03.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=gdK7nh3iA-PZWJRWvw5QDeKkoWciVolgjZvyXXmUXbUpq9Zp9LlYgPJbJAv0G2KcQrKKlWw~94iefBwUlRD7ypKV~2s9bZf8SM4GPX~LK0gFSmGPaa356HvQE-xSWsxAzQlshLNWMyE0pKZ~c2ULgvgWpxEgvIdgxu0kP3t5QjM03WkubELQrF7sxzqUbIFXTlQjoBsQnQbXybXgA1Pw~BeTIoarHDUnc149Rh~Ly1ik~aA1bbo8Sap8TgvUuyL8rU~149zW8U1Hcisrn9Wfd6Jj~VUQv8Rk~4WHn-Zs5j5j2Pgs3NWWbURy3AsMdjSWsISYl928jMoV3XAfugjrgA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with hostlens. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec2. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in JKs) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the r and i bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a05).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515716/stz1142fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515716\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=k2mmeKiMU8GbX~MXSPUwLQNDSc~As8RhreeHtxwTq2OuC4sX7gxiMr4n4J3DgWKRBNapSB0yLKfCP8KE0LL0PpxZL9iT3TjxE3Kmingvsti99cS5g07n0rmWkBtzhHUlTzrhVZrFDWHjZbBHF8vcuNV-3i5hqddsONQwM9HxYYQr0r7Tmj3q5AnY1v~vlbh0nx8gkOuI8UyKCYHY07evHeTIgzK~Rw5iCfW463UxE4VgMV2fon4ybiVpYgj-z~c7nrpSYp1-wwh2wcn7yHaZPsaxR~JRm6VKm65V~s9F0s1moHxvO~MN1A4w-l0paUMswPECMTLh0q2bvugRwwbcHg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515716&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup>. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in <em>JKs</em>) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a03.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=gdK7nh3iA-PZWJRWvw5QDeKkoWciVolgjZvyXXmUXbUpq9Zp9LlYgPJbJAv0G2KcQrKKlWw~94iefBwUlRD7ypKV~2s9bZf8SM4GPX~LK0gFSmGPaa356HvQE-xSWsxAzQlshLNWMyE0pKZ~c2ULgvgWpxEgvIdgxu0kP3t5QjM03WkubELQrF7sxzqUbIFXTlQjoBsQnQbXybXgA1Pw~BeTIoarHDUnc149Rh~Ly1ik~aA1bbo8Sap8TgvUuyL8rU~149zW8U1Hcisrn9Wfd6Jj~VUQv8Rk~4WHn-Zs5j5j2Pgs3NWWbURy3AsMdjSWsISYl928jMoV3XAfugjrgA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with hostlens. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec2. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in JKs) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the r and i bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a05).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515716/stz1142fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515716\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=k2mmeKiMU8GbX~MXSPUwLQNDSc~As8RhreeHtxwTq2OuC4sX7gxiMr4n4J3DgWKRBNapSB0yLKfCP8KE0LL0PpxZL9iT3TjxE3Kmingvsti99cS5g07n0rmWkBtzhHUlTzrhVZrFDWHjZbBHF8vcuNV-3i5hqddsONQwM9HxYYQr0r7Tmj3q5AnY1v~vlbh0nx8gkOuI8UyKCYHY07evHeTIgzK~Rw5iCfW463UxE4VgMV2fon4ybiVpYgj-z~c7nrpSYp1-wwh2wcn7yHaZPsaxR~JRm6VKm65V~s9F0s1moHxvO~MN1A4w-l0paUMswPECMTLh0q2bvugRwwbcHg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515716&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup>. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in <em>JKs</em>) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data we do not detect any sign of the lensing galaxy, which however stands out in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a>,<em>J</em> and <em>Ks</em> images. We model its light profile in these bands simultaneously with the quasar images, using a de Vaucouleurs (de Vaucouleurs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1948</a>) profile commonly used for early-type lensing galaxies. A circular profile fits the emission from the lensing galaxy well, without leaving noticeable residuals. Using a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach, we find that the lensing galaxy flux is highly degenerate with the effective radius of the de Vaucouleurs profile, and is therefore unreliable.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to perform gravitational lens modelling of 2M1134\u22122103 we need to estimate reliable relative astrometry for the quasar images and the lensing galaxy. For the three brightest quasar images we take the mean and scatter between the measured relative astrometry in different filters (excluding <em>g</em> band, where the seeing is significantly larger, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), whereas for the lensing galaxy and the faint counterimage D, we only use the <em>J</em> and <em>Ks</em> filters. Indeed, the separation between the brighter images (A, B, and C) and the fainter counterimage (D) decreases slightly with increasing wavelength in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> images, because of the progressively increasing flux contribution from the red lensing galaxy. We report our measured astrometry and photometry in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Our astrometry is consistent with the one presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a> within our 2\u03c3 uncertainties.</p>                        <a id=\"135515719\" scrollto-destination=\"135515719\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a02.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p (20.1)\u00a0</td><td>15.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.009\u00a0</td><td>16.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.027\u00a0</td><td>[17.33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry is determined by using information from multiple filters (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>). The units are in arcsec and the sign convention is positive from E to W (<em>x</em>-axis) and from S to N (<em>y</em>-axis). The ICRS position of image A in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue is (J2000.0) 11:34:40.588\u201321:03:23.06. Magnitudes are in the AB (<em>grizy</em>) and Vega (<em>YJKs</em>) systems, and are corrected for Galactic extinction following Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The 1\u03c3 limiting magnitudes are computed in 2\u2009arcsec-radius blank sky apertures around the system. The errors on magnitudes are those from MCMC, with the minimum uncertainty boosted to 0.005 mag, and do not include zero-point or PSF uncertainties. The magnitudes of G and GX (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) should be considered unreliable, as in order for the fit to converge, the effective radius was fixed to &lt;1\u00a0pixel.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515719\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a02.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry and absolute photometry of 2M1134\u22122103.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Filter (lim. mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n (24.2)\u00a0</td><td>17.08\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.37\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.014\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.70\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>r</em> (24.5)\u00a0</td><td>16.85\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.00\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.67\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[23.37\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10]\u00a0</td><td>1.20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>i</em> (24.5)\u00a0</td><td>16.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.88\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[21.75\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08]\u00a0</td><td>1.20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>z</em> (23.6)\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.49\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>y</em> (22.6)\u00a0</td><td>16.79\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>16.72\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>16.70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>18.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Y</em> (21.4)\u00a0</td><td>15.92\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.012\u00a0</td><td>[19.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Ks</em> class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Filter (lim. mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>A<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>all (23.6)\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.49\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>y</em> (22.6)\u00a0</td><td>16.79\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>16.72\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>16.70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>18.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Y</em> (22.2)\u00a0</td><td>16.08\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008\u00a0</td><td>15.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.007\u00a0</td><td>16.02\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.007\u00a0</td><td>17.57\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.016\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>J</em> (21.4)\u00a0</td><td>15.92\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.012\u00a0</td><td>[19.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Ks</em> (20.1)\u00a0</td><td>15.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.009\u00a0</td><td>16.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.027\u00a0</td><td>[17.33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry is determined by using information from multiple filters (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>). The units are in arcsec and the sign convention is positive from E to W (<em>x</em>-axis) and from S to N (<em>y</em>-axis). The ICRS position of image A in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue is (J2000.0) 11:34:40.588\u201321:03:23.06. Magnitudes are in the AB (<em>grizy</em>) and Vega (<em>YJKs</em>) systems, and are corrected for Galactic extinction following Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The 1\u03c3 limiting magnitudes are computed in 2\u2009arcsec-radius blank sky apertures around the system. The errors on magnitudes are those from MCMC, with the minimum uncertainty boosted to 0.005 mag, and do not include zero-point or PSF uncertainties. The magnitudes of G and GX (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) should be considered unreliable, as in order for the fit to converge, the effective radius was fixed to &lt;1\u00a0pixel.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515719\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515720 id=\"135515720\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 2M1134\u22122103: KECK SPECTROSCOPY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The 2M1134\u22122103 lens system was observed with the Echellette Spectrograph and Imager (ESI; Sheinis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) on the night of 2017 November 18 <span class=\"small-caps\">ut</span> (program number 2017B_U110). The observations utilized a slit with a width of 1\u2009arcsec and the cross-dispersed Echellette mode of the spectrograph, which provides a constant dispersion of roughly 11.5\u00a0km\u00a0sec<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pix<sup>\u22121</sup> over a wavelength range of approximately 3900\u201311\u2009000\u00a0\u00c5. Here, we follow the nomenclature of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>. Two slit position angles were used, one oriented at +46.7\u2009deg (N through E) in order to go across lensed images B and C (henceforth the \u2018BC slit\u2019) and one oriented at \u221242.3\u2009deg to cover images A and D (the \u2018AD slit\u2019). We obtained three 600\u00a0s exposures through the BC slit and four 600\u00a0s exposures through the AD slit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We calibrated the data using a custom pipeline written in <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>. The pipeline does a flat-field correction, rectifies the two-dimensional spectra, does the wavelength calibration using both arc lamp and night sky emission lines, and subtracts the sky emission. The calibrated data for both slits are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. In the AD slit, the two-dimensional spectra show one bright trace that is heavily blended with a much fainter trace, while the BC slit shows three clearly separated traces. We identify the three traces in the BC slit with components B, A+D+G, and C in the imaging data. Based on the imaging, we expect that the emission from image A completely dominates the central trace.</p>                        <a id=\"135515723\" scrollto-destination=\"135515723\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=XAiLJio2tUDAnjVevePbGPIYw4aygOI~1ACRmbZmzRWAEAfEpbdh-0fetHfw8lolx2RdQunYe5gC95XsRt3MMp0v0qSQV8kJgOEEuW1BxyYnotlyQyF1HetNLnEVyJLTJ8qnV8OXss5EceOOkPPX~~I2SYv3gVqgFKGi1Bu-Qs-OuoI2eytWyqC5upY9BBG~0YdtxafsvBm0c~BZIQKWo7Oyi6r1mdcI5nJhBqVLRC~AsuizWlnGxG4PG~xik0IDWUtYp8SUrhly3-CXPdyRtMvvdDopRWDXI5WEWU0V0XI4UbUnvGkc3hdb~OzgxTKycSSqj3XeyWyYec2Sus3XbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515723/stz1142fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515723\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=GNApqDcJf2NGQ0OmkfVHBQgD-fFlMW5y5Nm4IX4oRXpxafWdcpa2Y8Ub4hCuAw-pyJ8Kt~Nul0efSRRrbnFNa-OiMqpycob9Z7Who38M2CUw5guqdSzWyWXILnF1-ir~q1KZKOlFgSgh54N5gurM5RiffDVOjg7Y8Q8oVjF1JhLIxQEsCX2CfoKmLx44NTEp~tOmDiMpc83adtO6rFP4k0IE4XVR8OqbSxhtePqWaEhPe-qbSK-r8aejC01AL2txfQ9sClhZ3KdW~IPlAbsFRhyAtlm6D~NsXTFomC6xZpL2D465o3wNtV5xTPb9NB4mtkFSe4IBpdEfJbkEpO81wA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515723&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=XAiLJio2tUDAnjVevePbGPIYw4aygOI~1ACRmbZmzRWAEAfEpbdh-0fetHfw8lolx2RdQunYe5gC95XsRt3MMp0v0qSQV8kJgOEEuW1BxyYnotlyQyF1HetNLnEVyJLTJ8qnV8OXss5EceOOkPPX~~I2SYv3gVqgFKGi1Bu-Qs-OuoI2eytWyqC5upY9BBG~0YdtxafsvBm0c~BZIQKWo7Oyi6r1mdcI5nJhBqVLRC~AsuizWlnGxG4PG~xik0IDWUtYp8SUrhly3-CXPdyRtMvvdDopRWDXI5WEWU0V0XI4UbUnvGkc3hdb~OzgxTKycSSqj3XeyWyYec2Sus3XbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515723/stz1142fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515723\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=GNApqDcJf2NGQ0OmkfVHBQgD-fFlMW5y5Nm4IX4oRXpxafWdcpa2Y8Ub4hCuAw-pyJ8Kt~Nul0efSRRrbnFNa-OiMqpycob9Z7Who38M2CUw5guqdSzWyWXILnF1-ir~q1KZKOlFgSgh54N5gurM5RiffDVOjg7Y8Q8oVjF1JhLIxQEsCX2CfoKmLx44NTEp~tOmDiMpc83adtO6rFP4k0IE4XVR8OqbSxhtePqWaEhPe-qbSK-r8aejC01AL2txfQ9sClhZ3KdW~IPlAbsFRhyAtlm6D~NsXTFomC6xZpL2D465o3wNtV5xTPb9NB4mtkFSe4IBpdEfJbkEpO81wA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515723&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We extracted one-dimensional spectra from the exposures on both slits using a second Python pipeline that extracts the spectra from each spectral order, applies a response correction based on observations of a spectrophotometric standard, in this case Feige\u00a0110, and finally combines the data from each of the 10 spectral orders into one final spectrum. For the AD slit, we only extracted one aperture that we identify with a blend of A, D, and G, while for the BC slit we extracted separate apertures corresponding to B, A+D+G, and C. Note that the AD slit may very well contain significant scattered light from images B and C. The extracted spectra are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and all show clear broad emission lines that, furthermore, are indicative of quasars at a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>src</sub> \u223c 2.77. Thus, the ESI spectra are fully consistent with the interpretation of 2M1134\u22122103 as a quad lensed quasar. An exact value of the source redshift is difficult to obtain due to the fact that the peaks of the lines used for redshift determination are affected by absorption systems (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>; also e.g. Lee <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The measured redshift is smaller than the <em>z</em> \u223c 3.5 estimate in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> colours.</p>                        <a id=\"135515725\" scrollto-destination=\"135515725\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=ZPRChnIFMMwiXhwEvyNGZmhZTR4NpCZg8RJSjMtWvXEA8Jl4M69idI4c0SWFu0Wn8JcqgwPAGynaKSZLtCoB8iDaswCUZhq97wR5dOfxE~o3sdvIWgVRn1p8CFTl15gGQGkZAaZZO9AbxVdz2AtAiObOg5Qzo~X7zfH6aSVLJ~R3nGGLMzreD2O4eSCtqGz4FZDPuDDnL~Ts3aVmC~gIp~IcoP9ejjuMJBeL0itMtkLxWvWBeLSGrsUo39UkIzFKcGbiLH0bPc1J5RG2Wq6KRoBAxF2sHcCnBTfoKx5~I9hvscL3xkD96Pz911HKHe68zAmZQVpVCcd7zbeJU5N43A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Combined light from lensed images A and D, plus any emission from the lensing galaxy is visible in the spectrum extracted from the AD slit (green) as well as that from the BC slit (dark blue) in the top panel. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a04). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515725/stz1142fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515725\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=nWgSkQvxPThCJW~ERoqRW4c6XfzPt1xOzNFeSQ-6CD2oT29DqlCctQlHpqXUsdtI6GR37Ph5Zbkopd7Y7kIZ5kmsu~M~FzTyZJ9XnA4mVCNary8AFOyBOjqkh~0D83uZie4hzj4UnV3RIzdV~Cx54i-QX2PfCkY~1RWNnBq80WABTpah-11tx2UN1d9K-vQDcI26hJqNjWNvvaiqM64zegU4SpRXsSEQ7Hn0syVrjYf1bcbEodCK5l-TaeSnyamokvgyEJcTXcY7XP1aUp0-VZAjTtPG3NSqe7sYKKPqIB1Vr8IpiELPSbkQWjHDJKXWVhBwpz5aupqzw6KPbJFDPg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515725&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Combined light from lensed images A and D, plus any emission from the lensing galaxy is visible in the spectrum extracted from the AD slit (green) as well as that from the BC slit (dark blue) in the top panel. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=ZPRChnIFMMwiXhwEvyNGZmhZTR4NpCZg8RJSjMtWvXEA8Jl4M69idI4c0SWFu0Wn8JcqgwPAGynaKSZLtCoB8iDaswCUZhq97wR5dOfxE~o3sdvIWgVRn1p8CFTl15gGQGkZAaZZO9AbxVdz2AtAiObOg5Qzo~X7zfH6aSVLJ~R3nGGLMzreD2O4eSCtqGz4FZDPuDDnL~Ts3aVmC~gIp~IcoP9ejjuMJBeL0itMtkLxWvWBeLSGrsUo39UkIzFKcGbiLH0bPc1J5RG2Wq6KRoBAxF2sHcCnBTfoKx5~I9hvscL3xkD96Pz911HKHe68zAmZQVpVCcd7zbeJU5N43A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Combined light from lensed images A and D, plus any emission from the lensing galaxy is visible in the spectrum extracted from the AD slit (green) as well as that from the BC slit (dark blue) in the top panel. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a04). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515725/stz1142fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515725\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=nWgSkQvxPThCJW~ERoqRW4c6XfzPt1xOzNFeSQ-6CD2oT29DqlCctQlHpqXUsdtI6GR37Ph5Zbkopd7Y7kIZ5kmsu~M~FzTyZJ9XnA4mVCNary8AFOyBOjqkh~0D83uZie4hzj4UnV3RIzdV~Cx54i-QX2PfCkY~1RWNnBq80WABTpah-11tx2UN1d9K-vQDcI26hJqNjWNvvaiqM64zegU4SpRXsSEQ7Hn0syVrjYf1bcbEodCK5l-TaeSnyamokvgyEJcTXcY7XP1aUp0-VZAjTtPG3NSqe7sYKKPqIB1Vr8IpiELPSbkQWjHDJKXWVhBwpz5aupqzw6KPbJFDPg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515725&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Combined light from lensed images A and D, plus any emission from the lensing galaxy is visible in the spectrum extracted from the AD slit (green) as well as that from the BC slit (dark blue) in the top panel. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the broad emission lines, all of the spectra show a number of absorption lines. In the range 5000\u20137500\u2009\u00c5, these correspond to absorption features of Fe and Mg, and are consistent with two separate absorption systems at <em>z</em><sub>abs,1</sub>\u00a0= 1.554 and <em>z</em><sub>abs,2</sub>\u00a0= 1.481. The first system has stronger lines in the A+D+G and B spectra, while the second is stronger in the image C spectrum. Although it is possible that these systems may be associated with the primary lensing galaxy, the narrowness of the lines makes this interpretation unlikely. A much stronger indication of the lensing galaxy would be the detection of stellar absorption lines, such as the Ca\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> H and K lines, with widths consistent with the velocity dispersions of &gt;100\u00a0km s<sup>\u22121</sup> expected for a massive lensing galaxy. If these corresponded to the redshifts of the absorption features mentioned above, they would be observed at wavelengths longer than the ones plotted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, where we have extracted robust spectra.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515727 id=\"135515727\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 2M1134\u22122103: G\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ravitational lens modelling</span></h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We perform gravitational lens mass modelling of 2M1134\u22122103 with <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), using the observed relative positions of the quasar images and the lensing galaxy as constraints. We do not impose constraints based on the flux ratios, as these might be affected by microlensing, extinction, and intrinsic variability (e.g. Yonehara, Hirashita\u00a0&amp; Richter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). However, we analyse the observed flux ratios under the assumptions that they are dominated by extinction, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We start with the same mass model used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, a singular isothermal sphere with external shear (SIS+\u03b3). This model has \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 7.5/3 (where d.o.f. stands for degrees of freedom), most of which is due to the difference between the measured and predicted position of image D relative to the lens G. We recover the results of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, in particular that an unusually large shear of \u223c0.34 at 44\u00a0deg W of N is required to fit this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Secondly, we fit a model which allows for mass ellipticity, SIE+\u03b3. Indeed, quads have enough constraints to disentangle internal and external sources of shear, and our fit shows a dramatic improvement to \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 0.1/1. This model requires a shear of \u223c0.39, slightly larger than before, and a mass axial ratio of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.80^{+0.10}_{-0.18}$|\u2060</span>, with the long axis at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$37^{+5}_{-13}$|</span> deg E of N, almost perpendicular to that of the shear. While our imaging data does not have sufficient resolution to fit an elliptical light profile to the lensing galaxy, studies of quads show that the mass and light profiles of lensing galaxies are typically aligned (e.g. Keeton, Kochanek\u00a0&amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We note that Rusu\u00a0&amp; Lemon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) modelled a different quad, GraL\u00a0J1817+2729, in a cross-like configuration, and showed that while an SIE+\u03b3 model required large shear and large ellipticity, with the long axis perpendicular to the shear, similar to the present case, a Sersic+SIS+\u03b3 model, where the Sersic component stands for the baryonic matter in the disc of the lensing galaxy, significantly diminishes the required shear, and changes its orientation. We attempted to fit such as model here, but it behaves equivalently to our SIE+\u03b3 model, requiring similar orientation and large shear. It appears that the highly stretched, diamond-like configuration, cannot be explained by internal sources of shear.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As both the SIS+\u03b3 and SIE+\u03b3 models are consistent in their requirement of large external shear, we look for potential sources of shear from the surrounding environment. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> we display a 60\u00a0\u00d7 60\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup> colour composite image around 2M1134\u22122103, which clearly shows a group of red galaxies in the upper right corner, the brightest of which is a <em>i</em>\u00a0= 19.32 galaxy located at \u03b1\u00a0= 173.6620, \u03b4\u00a0= \u221221.0502, 30\u2009arcsec from the quad, in the direction of 45\u00a0deg W of N. The <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> colours of this galaxy imply a photometric redshift of 0.70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09, estimated with <span class=\"monospace\">BPZ</span> (Ben\u00edtez <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). The existence of the galaxy group at this location implies that it is responsible for part of the measured shear. However this is unlikely to be the complete picture, as an SIS profile at the location of this galaxy would require a very large velocity dispersion \u22731100\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> to produce the measured shear, depending on the redshift of the lensing galaxy in 2M1134\u22122103.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> reveals another clue, closer to 2M1134\u22122103. After subtracting the quasar images, an additional component is detected in filters <em>r</em> and <em>i</em>, 4.16\u2009arcsec from image A, also in the direction of the shear, towards south-east. It is unclear whether this new component, which we name GX, is a galaxy or a star, as it is too faint (<em>i</em> \u223c 21.75) to constrain its morphology. Under the assumption that it is a galaxy, its colours suggest a redshift lower than the one of the lensing galaxy, which is only detected in the near-infrared <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> filters. We incorporate GX into a third lensing model, in order to estimate its effect on the external shear. As we do not know the redshifts for either G or GX, we consider the simplest case in which G and GX are modelled as SIS of equal strength, at the same redshift. This model is expected to be an upper limit to the contribution of GX to the lensing configuration, as GX is likely a lower redshift, low-mass galaxy. We obtain a good fit with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 2.3/3, and a residual external shear of \u223c0.19, oriented as before. In this model, the two lenses are located \u223c4 Einstein radii apart, in units of the Einstein radius of G. Our model shows that GX can explain a significant fraction of the shear we measured in our initial SIS+\u03b3 model. We expect that in reality most of the measured shear is an interplay between the effects of GX and the nearby group. In our model incorporating GX, the nearby group would still require a velocity dispersion of \u223c800\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> to account for the remaining shear, which would imply \u227350 group/cluster members (e.g. Berlind et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). While we do not see more than \u223c3 possible galaxy members in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> image, this is not an argument against the existence of this structure, as the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> images are shallow. Indeed, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> images of the system RX\u00a0J0911+05 reveal only \u223c5 galaxies part of a spectroscopically confirmed cluster with at least 24 members at a similar redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.769, with velocity dispersion \u223c800\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Kneib, Cohen\u00a0&amp; Hjorth <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), giving rise to a very large shear \u22730.3 (Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that another lensed system with a remarkably similar diamond-like configuration has recently been discovered (Bettoni et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) close to a galaxy cluster, also with a large measured shear of 0.31 and a nearby galaxy in the direction of the shear. Finally, we note that highly sheared quadruple lens systems are not unexpected, and are a consequence of the tendency of elliptical galaxies, which constitute most of the lensing galaxies, to reside in overdense regions with high shear (e.g. Holder\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). We conclude that the large shear values we measure do not therefore point out to a problem with our mass models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the analysis above we did not assume particular values of source and lens redshifts, except when we estimated the velocity dispersion of the galaxy group at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.7. The flux ratios are also insensitive to the choice of redshifts, however the estimated time delays depend on them. To estimate the time delays, which are of interest to cosmography studies (e.g. Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we use the source quasar redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0= 2.77 measured from spectroscopy, and the lens redshift limits we infer below in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>, <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.45\u00a0\u2212\u00a01.5. For <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.45 and the SIS+\u03b3 model, the estimated time delays are \u0394CB \u223c 7\u00a0d, \u0394CA \u223c 30\u00a0d, and \u0394CD \u223c 55\u00a0d. The order of the image time arrival is the same in all three models, with image C leading. We summarize the main parameters of the mass models we employed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, along with the corresponding time delays.</p>                        <a id=\"135515735\" scrollto-destination=\"135515735\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a03.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the best-fitting parameter values of the lensing mass models, and the predicted time delays.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3 (km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>e</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CB<span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>243.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>30.5\u00a0</td><td>6.8\u00a0</td><td>54.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>384.1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>196.6\u00a0</td><td>43.9\u00a0</td><td>353.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>242.1\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>24.7\u00a0</td><td>6.3\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>382.6\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>159.0\u00a0</td><td>40.3\u00a0</td><td>281.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>233.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>33.9\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>44.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>363.4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>225.9\u00a0</td><td>49.3\u00a0</td><td>263.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf7\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here <em>z</em> is the lens redshift, \u03c3 is the lens velocity dispersion, <em>e</em> and \u03b3 are the lens ellipticity and shear, respectively, and \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> and \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub> are their orientations (W of N). The time delays (last column) are in units of days.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515735\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515736 id=\"135515736\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Flux ratio analysis and the lens redshift</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We show the measured image flux ratios in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, based on Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. At least three of the six ratios show a clear dependence on wavelength. Interpreted as due to extinction, these ratios imply that A is the least reddened image, in agreement with image D being closest to the lensing galaxy, and the major axis of the lensing galaxy being oriented towards B and C (with B more reddened then C), according to the SIE+\u03b3 model. We also show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> the predicted flux ratios given by the SIS+\u03b3 model. The predicted SIE+\u03b3 fluxes are very similar, within <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }10{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, but the G+GX+\u03b3 model predicts a demagnified image A, about as bright as D. All models predict image B to be the brightest, as observed in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> data. The predicted B/C is invariant across all three models, as the shear is almost perpendicular to the direction of these two images. In fact, this ratio is the only one which matches the observations, in the reddest filter.</p>                        <a id=\"135515738\" scrollto-destination=\"135515738\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a06.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=bXNlZxDLyQDxUr0sf3o0VuU01P56TG2WsuU-tHWtauuERvBfvoslSyH0xuYcvjWxkDSZIgeIRV9xJSTlibter4QCUBzfF5XG1BSL8ookUIiVyqQj-4PPrOmYmpxvZtuvvUAlFUPCtCt3WUZBWrrM6Y7nYH0dKibRaZREf9SrgyCXjSxardA8mn2f7t0hSvDztAgndAMZ3KZ~kLNKOHh0BI3GR1FzYvynBVopRsXQNtU5~-DH2slmXnQe5DneTjpCPQWB~k5Vfa6dW0Y-wUAyWv9VZL15PKquzIgZ14b0SMTQPSi~Tl1WKc9GjrZTlKYb4xe2kGDyoiFwfstnQ-cXVw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured and model-predicted flux ratios of the four quasar images.
