Thick lines connect observed flux ratios in all available filters, and thin horizontal lines of corresponding colours mark the flux ratios predicted by the SIS+\u03b3 lens mass model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a06.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=bXNlZxDLyQDxUr0sf3o0VuU01P56TG2WsuU-tHWtauuERvBfvoslSyH0xuYcvjWxkDSZIgeIRV9xJSTlibter4QCUBzfF5XG1BSL8ookUIiVyqQj-4PPrOmYmpxvZtuvvUAlFUPCtCt3WUZBWrrM6Y7nYH0dKibRaZREf9SrgyCXjSxardA8mn2f7t0hSvDztAgndAMZ3KZ~kLNKOHh0BI3GR1FzYvynBVopRsXQNtU5~-DH2slmXnQe5DneTjpCPQWB~k5Vfa6dW0Y-wUAyWv9VZL15PKquzIgZ14b0SMTQPSi~Tl1WKc9GjrZTlKYb4xe2kGDyoiFwfstnQ-cXVw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured and model-predicted flux ratios of the four quasar images. Thick lines connect observed flux ratios in all available filters, and thin horizontal lines of corresponding colours mark the flux ratios predicted by the SIS+\u03b3 lens mass model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515738/stz1142fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515738\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=zgWWbcx0nTJNMq3nBx9ZDjGckLoemjd-BBWzMEazXTECWz0dx-k0nt4H4u1UlAZfYR2~xPXf-S9PqdkjvZAiV47LSn~ILDo5bila022jM58gKfz4XwRNzCU~74UaL7PATZZrpt3v3Tu35DRyOtvLyW1TM~0mh7YvE3WsI2NTLh49cbP~D0fTLGRkyPl8qVMXXCkhnuvBeqE25qaiqeKh3vwxMxA2rwEiVDCQUrAYRbBIlt-b2WZx-ip2tF7qbkYeCWuCw0C9BDUpsa025KbZ~2MDsylpyXFCVwSMg8I4WprpigF4NcWaAxkItxf4hyMPt6XoDDlx3hs-DRt65VOnKQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515738&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured and model-predicted flux ratios of the four quasar images. Thick lines connect observed flux ratios in all available filters, and thin horizontal lines of corresponding colours mark the flux ratios predicted by the SIS+\u03b3 lens mass model.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Flux ratios of quasar images have been used in the past to study the extinction properties of lensing galaxies (e.g. Falco et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) as well as to infer lens redshifts (e.g. Jean\u00a0&amp; Surdej <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). Here, we use them to infer the lens redshift <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> as well as the de-reddened flux ratios (relative magnifications) <em>M<sub>i</sub></em>, where <em>i</em> refers to each of the six image pairs, independent of the chosen mass model. Following Falco et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), we optimize these parameters as well as the differential extinctions <em>E<sub>i</sub></em> and the shape of the extinction curve <em>R</em> by minimizing <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\chi ^2=\\sum _{j=1}^{N_\\lambda }\\sum _{i=1}^{N_\\mathrm{imag}}{\\frac{\\left[m^r_i(\\lambda _j)-m^b_i(\\lambda _j) - 2.5\\log M_i - E_iR\\left(\\frac{\\lambda _j}{1+z_l}\\right) \\right]^2}{\\sigma ^{b,2}_{ij}+\\sigma ^{r,2}_{ij}}} \\nonumber\\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>j</em> is the filter index, superscripts <em>b</em> and <em>r</em> refer to the blue and red images in each pair, respectively, and \u03c3<sub><em>ij</em></sub> is the magnitude measurement uncertainty. We use the central wavelength of each filter, and the Cardelli, Clayton\u00a0&amp; Mathis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) extinction function implemented in the code <span class=\"small-caps\">extinction</span>.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">10</a></sup> We perform the minimization using the Nelder\u2013Mead (Nelder\u00a0&amp; Mead <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1965</a>) method implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">scipy</span> (Oliphant <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), starting from random positions in the parameter space and further exploring around the solution with <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> (Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), to ensure that we have found the global solution.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find the best-fitting solution (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 213.4/16)<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn11\" data-open=\"fn11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">11</a></sup> with <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.45, <em>R</em> \u223c 2.5 slightly smaller than the Galactic extinction curve with <em>R<sub>V</sub></em>\u00a0= 3.1, small <em>E<sub>i</sub></em>\u00a0\u2272\u00a00.1 consistent with the results in Falco et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), and flux ratios B/A\u00a0=\u00a01.28, C/A\u00a0=\u00a01.20, D/A\u00a0=\u00a00.30. These parameter values are robust if we remove from the fit all image pairs containing D (new fit \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 145.8/10), in case our decomposition of G and D is problematic due to the low image resolution. They are also robust to the choice of the extinction function. Except for B/C, which matches the prediction of the mass models, the flux ratios are smaller than predicted. The quality of the fits is statistically poor, although such large \u03c7<sup>2</sup> values are found by Falco et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) in other lensing systems as well. In our analysis, we have ignored any contribution from microlensing and quasar intrinsic variability, which can also affect flux ratios chromatically (e.g. Yonehara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We can look for signs of microlensing by plotting the quasar image spectral ratios. While the overall shape of these ratios is sensitive to observational effects such as suboptimal slit placement and differential refraction, these (as well as differential extinction) should affect both continua and emission lines equally. On the other hand, microlensing is dependent on the size of the source, such that the continuum emission, which originates from a more compact region than the broad emission lines, should be preferentially microlensed. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> clearly shows that, when dividing the fluxes of B and C to those of A<sub>BC</sub> (i.e. the A+D+G signal, dominated by A, and extracted from the BC slit) and of A<sub>AD</sub>, there is a large jump in the flux ratios at the locations of the SiV/OIV] (\u223c5270\u00c5) and CIV (\u223c5800\u00c5) broad-line regions, compared to the surrounding continuum. On the other hand, B/C is relatively flat over the entire plotted range, which means that microlensing affects image A+D (the saddle points of the time arrival surface) but not B and C. A direct comparison of the photometric flux ratios in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> with the spectroscopic ratios in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> is not possible due to the fact that the spectra are affected by slit losses. Indeed, this can be seen from the monotonic variation in A<sub>AD</sub>/A<sub>BC</sub>, which we attribute to the fact that ESI does not use an atmospheric dispersion corrector, thus resulting in flux losses from differential refraction, particularly between the orthogonally placed AD and BC slits. Also, the data sets are not concurrent, and are therefore prone to time-varying microlensing and intrinsic variability effects.</p>                        <a id=\"135515742\" scrollto-destination=\"135515742\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=kvQnKuT1DuS9b8vxSp1pN-DUHU6TQsRHN6D0XuXaV~g7e1CmEIjthlKq-DCjuccK2WljQN7iZc0xvnJ5Bs1YjM4epMWfq~ZiKw6ZxxHZIA5W8Kx-KN3UKgzrSvlBhqaVUP415onJTASwEseMkTZgZj4ZnJjrgVOgGWyIrYrATqWMX9AI7dfidA~vFMUHmZKCUOYLTn75QGtL7aG8sptnTRzV6jX1wxKleX1RbphtlUESuPV205WrnRo3GN9e53ri8Kk2TMByd-5UMWWgVU--vXY283syjdlgLno4DV-jomdZI2N3xfLZm0iyBQNEeOikuaLCjZzRFfgqs3RHQ0Tw8A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a06, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of AAD. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515742/stz1142fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515742\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=X8VSTOe2g7XAonhouecYPjmQFlfnn8o6BtxH7jljcfuHHzCEK5JxB6NkOCRzJHcF4-ffqgdOUiza2AIDxnhhd~eVfHrVQKtDCvxii2fOViQUVRapyZpZ5GDRD6b-~N5R0YyRUUGRPCFEYiWnlKmDoOm8lJryUMow3MFmCD9O~p9Olf1TQi7IgB68-3o7uxEn~L7sKD7jvUCUeE-wXs~m~EHB7DVHhAxTrr5N~VJdsxzYjjcN00Z~Zc9guqugI5VwcI4OtoWMWtINmUT7PFjvVU5L9OzsZqcInkdOIZW6eVllYXmhNAF2PcQnIySJD0~gQboYuaMOGnQwf~RHM05qVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515742&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of <em>A</em><sub>AD</sub>. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=kvQnKuT1DuS9b8vxSp1pN-DUHU6TQsRHN6D0XuXaV~g7e1CmEIjthlKq-DCjuccK2WljQN7iZc0xvnJ5Bs1YjM4epMWfq~ZiKw6ZxxHZIA5W8Kx-KN3UKgzrSvlBhqaVUP415onJTASwEseMkTZgZj4ZnJjrgVOgGWyIrYrATqWMX9AI7dfidA~vFMUHmZKCUOYLTn75QGtL7aG8sptnTRzV6jX1wxKleX1RbphtlUESuPV205WrnRo3GN9e53ri8Kk2TMByd-5UMWWgVU--vXY283syjdlgLno4DV-jomdZI2N3xfLZm0iyBQNEeOikuaLCjZzRFfgqs3RHQ0Tw8A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a06, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of AAD. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515742/stz1142fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515742\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=X8VSTOe2g7XAonhouecYPjmQFlfnn8o6BtxH7jljcfuHHzCEK5JxB6NkOCRzJHcF4-ffqgdOUiza2AIDxnhhd~eVfHrVQKtDCvxii2fOViQUVRapyZpZ5GDRD6b-~N5R0YyRUUGRPCFEYiWnlKmDoOm8lJryUMow3MFmCD9O~p9Olf1TQi7IgB68-3o7uxEn~L7sKD7jvUCUeE-wXs~m~EHB7DVHhAxTrr5N~VJdsxzYjjcN00Z~Zc9guqugI5VwcI4OtoWMWtINmUT7PFjvVU5L9OzsZqcInkdOIZW6eVllYXmhNAF2PcQnIySJD0~gQboYuaMOGnQwf~RHM05qVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515742&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of <em>A</em><sub>AD</sub>. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As discussed above, microlensing in particular may affect the inferred lens redshift. We note that due to the low image resolution, proximity to image D, and morphological compactness which may affect the extracted photometry, we could not obtain a robust photometric redshift for this galaxy. Looser but more robust redshift constraints can be set by using the observed image separation and the estimated magnitude of the lens in the filter in which it is brightest. On the one hand, the image separation gives the lens velocity dispersion as a function of redshift; on the other, assuming an early-type spectral template, the measured magnitude can be converted into a rest-frame absolute magnitude as a function of redshift,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn12\" data-open=\"fn12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">12</a></sup> and then into a velocity dispersion (Faber\u00a0&amp; Jackson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1976</a>). We find a lower limit of <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.5, below which the two velocity dispersion estimates disagree, and an upper limit of <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 1.5, above which the lens velocity dispersion is \u223c400\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, a value above which the galaxy velocity dispersion function is vanishingly small (Sheth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). The lower limit is close to the value inferred from our flux ratio analysis, and the upper one is consistent with the redshift of the narrow absorption systems identified in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>; it is also above the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a> estimate of <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 1.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515744 id=\"135515744\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have carried out a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>, based on visual examination of cut-outs around the AGN source catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and aided by astrometric quantities measured by <em>Gaia</em>. We present our sample of 91 promising candidates, not found in the available literature, in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, in order to enable follow-up observations by the interested community. We expect that the main source of contaminants are quasar pairs, which we see as a byproduct of our work, and to a lesser extent, quasar + star pairs. Our best estimate of the purity of our sample, in terms of lensed doubles and quasar pairs contaminated by quasar + star pairs, is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }70{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As part of our search, we have independently discovered six known quads, including 2M113\u22122103. We present, for the first time, spectroscopy of this system, confirming it as a lensed quasar with source redshift <em>z</em> \u223c 2.77. We identify absorption systems at <em>z</em> \u223c 1.5, in three of the resolved quasar images, but we find these to be too narrow to attribute to the lensing galaxy. The image flux ratios show a monotonic dependence on wavelength, which we use to obtain a rough estimate of the lens redshift, under the assumption that the dependence is caused by extinction. The spectral flux ratios show evidence of microlensing in the combined emission from images A and D.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our mass modelling confirms that 2M1134\u22122103 is affected by large shear, for which we identify two potential sources: a group of galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.7, 30\u2009arcsec from the lens, and another faint companion \u223c4\u2009arcsec away. Future multi-object spectroscopy is required to determine whether these are part of a larger cluster, or physically associated with the lens. The large image separation, brightness, and estimated time delays ranging from several days to several months, depending on the lens redshift, make this a valuable system to use for cosmography (e.g. Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), provided that the environment can be characterized with future, deep imaging and spectroscopy (e.g. Wilson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). High-resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> or adaptive optics imaging is necessary to constrain the morphology of the lensing galaxy, and to further constrain the mass models using the expected extended emission from the underlying host galaxy (e.g. Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515748 id=\"135515748\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors are indebted to the anonymous referee for thoroughly checking the sample of candidates, resulting in a significant improvement of our selection, and for suggesting the use of <em>Gaia</em>. We also wish to thank Paul L. Schechter for his \u2018matchmaking\u2019 which has made this paper possible. This research made use of <span class=\"small-caps\">astropy</span>, a community-developed core <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> package for Astronomy (Astropy Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Plots were produced with <span class=\"small-caps\">matplotlib</span> (Hunter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). This work was supported by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. CDF acknowledges support from the National Science Foundation under Grant No. AST-1715611.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>) and the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> public science archive have been made possible through contributions by the Institute for Astronomy, the University of Hawaii, the Pan-STARRS Project Office, the Max-Planck Society and its participating institutes, the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, Heidelberg and the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, Garching, The Johns Hopkins University, Durham University, the University of Edinburgh, the Queen\u2019s University Belfast, the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, the Las Cumbres Observatory Global Telescope Network Incorporated, the National Central University of Taiwan, the Space Telescope Science Institute, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration under Grant No. NNX08AR22G issued through the Planetary Science Division of the NASA Science Mission Directorate, the National Science Foundation Grant No. AST-1238877, the University of Maryland, Eotvos Lorand University (ELTE), the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work has made use of data from the European Space Agency (ESA) mission <em>Gaia</em> (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia</a>), processed by the <em>Gaia</em> Data Processing and Analysis Consortium (DPAC, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium</a>). Funding for the DPAC has been provided by national institutions, in particular the institutions participating in the <em>Gaia</em> Multilateral Agreement.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on observations obtained as part of the Visible and Infrared Survey Telescope for Astronomy (VISTA) Hemisphere Survey, ESO Progam, 179.A\u20132010 (PI: McMahon). Based on data obtained from the ESO Science Archive Facility under request number cerusu312487.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some of the data presented herein were obtained at the W. M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W. M. Keck Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this superb mountain.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515755 id=\"135515755\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Lemon, Auger\u00a0&amp; McMahon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) have compiled an up-to-date list of known lensed quasars, maintained at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/</a>. Also, C. Lemon, private communication.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We use the version available on Vizier, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR\" target=\"_blank\">http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR</a>, which contains fewer contaminants</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Following step <em>iii</em>, we explored using an additional step to eliminate globular clusters and similar crowded regions, by imposing the condition that there are no more than seven counterparts within 10\u2009arcsec radius. This would have eliminated only 182 systems, all of which we have explored visually, making this step unnecessary.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">In addition to these, two other lensed quasars survive our selection and grading process, but are not picked up by the cross-match with the catalogue of lenses because of differences in the reported coordinates: SDSS\u00a0J1320+1644 and SDSS\u00a0J1433+6007.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-fcoo\" target=\"_blank\">http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-fcoo</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/?q=nearposn\" target=\"_blank\">http://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/?q\u00a0=\u00a0nearposn</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn7\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://hla.stsci.edu/fitscutcgi_interface.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://hla.stsci.edu/fitscutcgi_interface.html</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Our chosen limits recover almost all of our confirmed candidates: among our 25 spectroscopically confirmed lenses or quasar pairs, only 2, both quads with four detected components in <em>Gaia</em>, would be (partially) ruled out based on our <em>Gaia</em> classifier: PSJ0147+4630 has one component with large parallax, and PSJ1606\u22122333 has one with large proper motion.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn9\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn9\" class=\"end-note-link\">9</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Note that it is presently unknown whether SDSS\u00a0J1320+1644, counted here as a double, is in fact a double or a quasar pair (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn10\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn10\" class=\"end-note-link\">10</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://extinction.readthedocs.io/en/latest/\" target=\"_blank\">http://extinction.readthedocs.io/en/latest/</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn11\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn11\" class=\"end-note-link\">11</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">With four images, thus three independent flux ratios in each band, and with eight bands, we have 24 constraints. As parameters, we have the redshift, the extinction curve parameter, three independent extinctions and 3 independent magnifications, thus eight parameters, resulting in 16 degrees of freedom.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn12\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn12\" class=\"end-note-link\">12</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">mag2mag</span> routine from Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/tcollett/LensPop/tree/master/stellarpop/\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/tcollett/LensPop/tree/master/stellarpop/</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn13\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn13\" class=\"end-note-link\">13</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.astro.rug.nl/\u00a0gaia/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.astro.rug.nl/\u00a0gaia/</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn14\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn14\" class=\"end-note-link\">14</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">From our 312 candidates, <em>G</em> \u2212 <em>g</em> has a distribution with a median of \u22120.21 and a standard deviation of 0.34</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515770 id=\"135515770\" L.</div></span> et al.\u00a0.</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">AJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">140</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1868</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\" class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib124\" data-legacy-id=\"bib124\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib124\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib124\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib124\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Yonehara</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Hirashita</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">H.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Richter</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2008</div>, <div class=\"source \">A&amp;A</div>, <div class=\"volume\">478</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">95</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361:20067014\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1051/0004-6361:20067014</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361:20067014\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1051%2F0004-6361:20067014\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1051%2F0004-6361:20067014\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib125\" data-legacy-id=\"bib125\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib125\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib125\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib125\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">York</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">D. G.</div></span> et al.\u00a0.</span>, <div class=\"year\">2000</div>, <div class=\"source \">AJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">120</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1579</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1086/301513\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1086/301513</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/301513\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1086%2F301513\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1086%2F301513\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515772 id=\"135515772\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX A: EXPECTED SAMPLE PURITY FROM THE RELATIVE DENSITY OF <em>GAIA</em> AND AGN SOURCES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We start with the complete <em>Gaia</em> DR2 source catalogue,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn13\" data-open=\"fn13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">13</a></sup> where we apply the same automatic selection cuts we used for our sample of candidates. We use a bright magnitude limit of <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2265\u00a017.5, slightly brighter than our candidate source companions, and a faint one of <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020. While 29 of the 91 candidate source companions are fainter than <em>G</em>\u00a0= 20, we apply this cut because <em>Gaia</em> DR2 is still complete at this limit (Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), outside the crowded regions excluded by our galactic latitude cut; the completeness is expected to drop towards the limiting magnitude of <em>G</em> \u223c 21. This reduces the <em>Gaia</em> catalogue to \u223c148 million sources. We also apply a colour cut of 0\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<em>Rp</em> \u2212 <em>Bp</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a01.5, from Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, as well as the same <em>Gaia</em>-based astrometric quantity cuts from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>. As we did for our candidates, we keep the objects without <em>Gaia</em> astrometric quantities or colour. This results in \u223c22 million remaining sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) AGN catalogue is less complete, but not significantly so, with a limiting magnitude of 20 in <em>g</em> band, or about the same in <em>Gaia G</em> band.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn14\" data-open=\"fn14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">14</a></sup> We use the Milliquas catalogue (Flesch <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), which is slightly more complete at this magnitude limit (see fig.\u00a03 in Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), and includes high-confidence quasars detected in X-ray and radio, in addition to <em>WISE</em>. We cross-matched the <em>Gaia</em> catalogue after performing the cuts described above with the Milliquas catalogue, resulting in \u223c520\u2009000 matches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, the <em>Gaia</em> resolution is much higher than the one of <em>WISE</em>, with PSF FWHM \u223c6\u2009arcsec (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We use <span class=\"small-caps\">topcat</span> (Taylor <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) to identify all objects from the <em>Gaia</em>-based catalogue we produced above with relative separation less than the <em>WISE</em> PSF FWHM, and count each of these clusters as one. This reduces the <em>Gaia</em>-based sample to \u223c14 million sources, resulting in an AGN fraction of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }4{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515776 id=\"135515776\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX B: PREVIOUSLY CONFIRMED OR RULED OUT CANDIDATES</h3>\r\n                        <a id=\"135515777\" scrollto-destination=\"135515777\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblB1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap The ones below are candidates ruled out either due to their <em>Gaia</em>-based properties, or due to spectroscopic results from the literature. The table structure is the same as in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table no <em>Gaia</em> data\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here \u03b1 and \u03b4 are the right ascension and declination of the candidates in the International Celestial Reference System. \u2018#Comp\u2019 refers to the number of components, where we use the number of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 sources inside 3\u2009arcsec radius, but revise it based on visual inspection, removing spurious sources and counting additional objects which appear to be part of the system. The measured separation (\u2018Sep.\u2019, in arcsec) is that between the lens candidate point sources or, in case of a quad, the maximum separation between any of the point sources, taken from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 catalogue, or revised as described above. The magnitude is given in <em>i</em> band in the AB system for the brightest resolved component. We quote the <span class=\"monospace\">iMeanPSFMag</span> measurements from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 catalogue, or the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span>1996) <span class=\"monospace\">MAG_AUTO</span> in case we had to manually add the brightest component of the system, as described above. We also quote the <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitudes for each system, in the order of increasing separation from the WISE source coordinates. Here \u2018p-l\u2019 stands for \u2018point-like\u2019, whereas \u2018AEN\u2019 (astrometric excess noise), \u2018p\u2019 (parallax), and \u2018pm\u2019 (proper motion) are <em>Gaia</em>-based measurements. We list in this table the alphabetic ranking as gravitationally lensed quasars for all systems with an average grade of 1 and above, based on three human graders, as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span>2. We follow the following convention for the alphabetic ranking: A: average grade &gt;2.5; B: average grade &gt;1.5; C: average grade \u22651. SQLS refers to the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span>2008, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span>2010, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span>2012). SDSS spectra were searched inside Data Release 14 (Abolfathi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span>2018).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup>a</sup>After the first draft of this work (arXiv:1803.07175v1), this system was independently announced by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span>2019) as a candidate. Our <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> modelling of the observed configuration with an SIE+\u03b3 mass profile results in a perfect fit, but the model is underconstrained because the lensing galaxy is not detected.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA; similar colour p-l; includes SDSS <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.797 QSO; SQLS candidate; both have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>220943+043217\u00a0</td><td>332.428196\u00a0</td><td>4.538084\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>18.18\u00a0</td><td>2.9\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>18.59, 18.40; similar colour p-l; both have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>222108+214518\u00a0</td><td>335.283056\u00a0</td><td>21.754907\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>17.34\u00a0</td><td>3.5\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>17.57; different colour p-l; only the main component has <em>Gaia</em> data, negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>230339+345343\u00a0</td><td>345.91142\u00a0</td><td>34.89518\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>18.36\u00a0</td><td>7.1\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>18.65, 18.98; similar colour p-l (both have negligible AEN, p, and pm) + inner red source\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>231813+025028\u00a0</td><td>349.554123\u00a0</td><td>2.841082\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>19.31\u00a0</td><td>3.2\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>19.59, 19.43; similar colour p-l; both have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>232223+375439\u00a0</td><td>350.595174\u00a0</td><td>37.910703\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>19.23\u00a0</td><td>2.2\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>19.87, 20.81; p-l; both have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>232449\u2212122555\u00a0</td><td>351.205773\u00a0</td><td>\u221212.432025\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>18.93\u00a0</td><td>1.8\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>19.25; p-l; only one component has <em>Gaia</em>data, negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>233525+184309\u00a0</td><td>353.85286\u00a0</td><td>18.71912\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>19.31\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>red components; no <em>Gaia</em> data\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here \u03b1 and \u03b4 are the right ascension and declination of the candidates in the International Celestial Reference System. \u2018#Comp\u2019 refers to the number of components, where we use the number of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 sources inside 3\u2009arcsec radius, but revise it based on visual inspection, removing spurious sources and counting additional objects which appear to be part of the system. The measured separation (\u2018Sep.\u2019, in arcsec) is that between the lens candidate point sources or, in case of a quad, the maximum separation between any of the point sources, taken from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 catalogue, or revised as described above. The magnitude is given in <em>i</em> band in the AB system for the brightest resolved component. We quote the <span class=\"monospace\">iMeanPSFMag</span> measurements from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>PS1 catalogue, or the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span>1996) <span class=\"monospace\">MAG_AUTO</span> in case we had to manually add the brightest component of the system, as described above. We also quote the <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitudes for each system, in the order of increasing separation from the WISE source coordinates. Here \u2018p-l\u2019 stands for \u2018point-like\u2019, whereas \u2018AEN\u2019 (astrometric excess noise), \u2018p\u2019 (parallax), and \u2018pm\u2019 (proper motion) are <em>Gaia</em>-based measurements. We list in this table the alphabetic ranking as gravitationally lensed quasars for all systems with an average grade of 1 and above, based on three human graders, as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span>2. We follow the following convention for the alphabetic ranking: A: average grade &gt;2.5; B: average grade &gt;1.5; C: average grade \u22651. SQLS refers to the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span>2008, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span>2010, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span>2012). SDSS spectra were searched inside Data Release 14 (Abolfathi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span>2018).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup>a</sup>After the first draft of this work (arXiv:1803.07175v1), this system was independently announced by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span>2019) as a candidate. Our <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> modelling of the observed configuration with an SIE+\u03b3 mass profile results in a perfect fit, but the model is underconstrained because the lensing galaxy is not detected.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SiteWideModals class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    A search for gravitationally lensed quasars and quasar pairs in Pan-STARRS1: spectroscopy and sources of shear in the diamond 2M1134\u22122103\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\"
