    <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515681 id=\"135515681\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present results of a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in Pan-STARRS1. Our final sample of candidates comprises of 91 systems, not including 25 rediscovered lensed quasars and quasar pairs. In the absence of spectroscopy to verify the lensing nature of the candidates, the main sources of contaminants are likely to be quasar pairs, which we consider to be a byproduct of our work, and a smaller number of quasar + star associations. Among the independently discovered quads is 2M1134\u22122103, for which we obtained spectroscopy for the first time, finding a redshift of 2.77 for the quasar. There is evidence for microlensing in at least one image. We perform detailed mass modelling of this system using archival imaging data, and find that the unusually large shear responsible for the diamond-like configuration can be attributed mainly to a faint companion \u223c4\u2009arcsec away, and to a galaxy group/cluster \u223c30\u2009arcsec away. We also set limits of <em>z</em> \u223c 0.5\u20131.5 on the redshift of the lensing galaxy, based on its brightness, the image separation of the lensed images, and an analysis of the observed photometric flux ratios.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: 2M1134\u22122103&quot;\">quasars: individual: 2M1134\u22122103</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515683 id=\"135515683\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To date, \u223c60 quadruple (quad) and \u223c200 double gravitationally lensed quasars have been discovered.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> Their value as probes of cosmology and astrophysics has been explored observationally for the past four decades (see e.g. reviews by Claeskens\u00a0&amp; Surdej <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Treu\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), yet their number is still a limiting factor for many focused studies (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We are currently in a post-Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) era when the large ongoing imaging surveys such as the Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System (Pan-STARRS1, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>; Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the Dark Energy Survey (Flaugher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and the Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru Strategic Program (Aihara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) do not (yet) have a spectroscopic counterpart, making it difficult to identify lensed quasars. As a result, contemporary dedicated searches for lensed quasars rely on selecting their candidates by applying machine learning techniques such as artificial neural networks (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) or Gaussian mixture models (e.g. Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Williams, Agnello\u00a0&amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) to multifilter photometric catalogues in conjunction with pixel-by-pixel pattern recognition; by looking for flux and position offsets between these surveys and <em>Gaia</em> (e.g. Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Agnello\u00a0&amp; Spiniello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), including capitalizing on the superior <em>Gaia</em> resolution to resolve blended sources (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018c</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Delchambre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and combining multiple such methods (e.g. Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>); by assessing the plausibility of valid lensing configurations on automatically detected sources (e.g. Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>); and/or by complementing these with variability information (e.g. Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Kostrzewa-Rutkowska et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Encouraged by the serendipitous discovery by Berghea et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) of the first quad from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>, PSOJ0147, we have begun a systematic search for lensed quasars in this survey, by cross-correlating sources with the parent active galactic nucleus (AGN) catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). As the first <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data were released in 2016 December, mining it for lensed quasars has only recently begun (e.g. Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), making it likely that other lensed quasars, including bright, large separation quads, are yet to be found. Given the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sky coverage and depth, Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) estimate that <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> contains \u223c2000 lensed quasars, including 300 quads.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recently, Lucey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>) have announced the discovery of a new bright, large-separation quad, 2M1134\u22122103. This was a serendipitous discovery, as part of a search for extended 2MASS (Skrutskie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) sources in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> footprint, to include as targets for the Taipan Galaxy Survey (da Cunha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). As part of our search, we have independently discovered this system. Here, we aim to present a more in-depth modelling of the archival imaging data, looking in particular to identify the cause for the unusually large shear inferred in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>. In addition, we present for the first time spectroscopic data for this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The structure of this paper is as follows: in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> we describe our search technique and a new sample of lensed quasars and quasar pair candidates. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> we describe our analysis of the archival imaging data of 2M1134\u22122103, and in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> our newly acquired spectroscopic data. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> we present our mass modelling of 2M1134\u22122103, and provide plausible explanations for the unusually large shear. We conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. Where necessary, we use a flat cosmology with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda =0.74$|</span> and <em>h</em>\u00a0= 0.72.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515688 id=\"135515688\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 A SEARCH FOR GRAVITATIONALLY LENSED QUASARS IN <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a></h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515689 id=\"135515689\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Selection based on catalogue cuts and visual inspection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> is a wide-field imaging system with a 1.8\u00a0m telescope and 7.7\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> field of view, located on the summit of Haleakala in the Hawaiian island of Maui. The 1.4 Gpixel camera consists of 60 CCDs with pixel size of 0.256 arcsec (Onaka\u00a0&amp; al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Tonry\u00a0&amp; Onaka <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The first <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data release includes both images and a photometry catalogue (Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> uses five SDSS-like filters (<em>g</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>r</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>i</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>z</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>, <em>y</em><sub><em>P</em>1</sub>). The largest survey <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> performs is the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3 \\pi$|</span> survey, covering the entire sky north of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-30\\deg$|</span> declination.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As we did for PSOJ0147, we start our search with the AGN candidates catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), based on two mid-infrared colours measured with the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We cross-correlate this catalogue with the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> (Flewelling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) using a 3\u2009arcsec radius cone search and keep 79\u2009951 candidates which have at least two counterparts (step <em>i</em>). Next, we remove candidates within 15 deg of the galactic plane, resulting in 64\u2009055 remaining sources (<em>ii</em>). We then impose a faint magnitude cut of <em>i</em>\u00a0= 19.5 on the closest counterpart, in order to eliminate spurious candidates. This results in 25\u2009493 sources remaining (<em>iii</em>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> Finally, we impose that the two brightest sources in each system should be similar in colour, removing the ones with <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> differences larger than 1.5 mag and <em>i</em> \u2212 <em>y</em> differences larger than 1.0 mag (<em>iv</em>). The final sample contains 18\u2009015 candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We chose these cuts in order to recover most of the known lenses at the intersection of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> and the Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) catalogue, while resulting in a number of candidates small enough to allow visual inspection. From an all-sky catalogue of \u223c260 known lenses (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), which we matched with the Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) catalogue to insure a match within 10\u2009arcsec, we found 45 lenses for which their Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) catalogue counterparts have at least two detections in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> within 3\u2009arcsec (corresponding to step <em>i</em>). These are further reduced to 44 (step <em>ii</em>), 32 (<em>iii</em>), and 30 lenses (<em>iv</em>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> In addition to the cross-match with the known catalogue of lensed quasars, we also looked for previously known non-lens systems, by cross-matching the coordinates of our candidates with the list of known sources from the SIMBAD Astronomical Data base<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> and the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Data base.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We downloaded 30\u00a0\u00d7 30\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup> postage stamp colour JPEG images of the candidates using the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> cut-out service,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> which were then inspected visually by three of the authors (CTB, ES, and GJN). Pairs with separation \u2272a few arcsec between components (consistent with strong lensing by galaxies) and similar colours, triplets with a redder inner component, as well as quads with configurations consistent with canonical lensing configurations were kept. Finally, another three authors (CER, AM, and GCFC) graded the remaining sample of 448 candidates. As is customary in the lens search community, they used the following grading system: 0: unlikely to be a lens; 1: possibly a lens candidate (satisfies only some criteria to be a lens); 2: probably a lens candidate (satisfies most criteria to be a lens); 3: almost certainly a lens (there is almost no doubt that this is a lens). We find 312 systems with an average grade \u22651, and discard the rest.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of the 312 candidates, we recover a total of 15 known lenses. Of these, 6 are quads: PS\u00a0J0147+4630 (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), 2M 1134\u22122103 (Lucey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1433+6007 (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>), GraL\u00a0J1537\u22123010 (Delchambre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), PS\u00a0J1606\u22122333 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and PS\u00a0J1721+8842 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and 9 are doubles: DES\u00a0J0245\u22120556 (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), PS\u00a0J0259\u22122338 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), HE 1104\u22121805 (Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), J1206\u22122543 (Lemon et\u00a0al. in preparation), SDSS\u00a0J1206+4332 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1320+1644 (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), ULAS\u00a0J1405+0959 (Jackson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1515+1511 (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and J2212+3144 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This means that at the grading stage we miss the cluster quad SDSS\u00a0J1004+4112 (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). In addition, at the initial visual inspection stage to produce the list for grading we miss the quad PG1115+080 (Weymann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) and 15 doubles: PS\u00a0J0028+0631 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), J0102+2445 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), Q0142\u2013100 (Surdej et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>), PS\u00a0J0949+4208 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1001+5027 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1313+5151 (Ofek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1349+1227 (Kayo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), SDSS\u00a0J1442+4055 (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), ULAS\u00a0J1527+0141 (Jackson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), PS\u00a0J2124+1632 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), another double from Ostrovski et\u00a0al. in preparation and four more doubles from Lemon et\u00a0al. in preparation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our cross-match with known lenses shows that we are more efficient at recovering quads than doubles, which is to be expected, because typical quad configurations are easier to identify visually. We are also biased against large-separation lenses, due to our requirement to have at least two components within 3\u2009arcsec. Since at the visual selection stage we miss 17/32 of the known lenses included in our cut-outs, we expect the completeness of our sample of candidates, defined as the ratio of the number of gravitational lenses in the final sample to the true number of lenses in the cut-outs, to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\lesssim } 50{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Most of these are missed at the initial visual inspection stage. This can be attributed to two factors: first, most of the missed systems are doubles with only two clearly visible components in the cut-outs, and with noticeable colour differences between the components. On the other hand, the authors who have inspected the 18\u2009015 candidates have no formal experience with gravitational lenses. When the authors with formal experience graded 11/17 missed lenses, 9 of these received an average grade \u22651.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that other known quads with bright lensing galaxies, such as 2M1310\u22121714 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>), are not included in our sample because the lens light contaminates the infrared colours that the Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) AGN catalogue is based on. Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) note that the chance of misclassifying stars in the AGN catalogue is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\le 0.041{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, so we expect that the main contaminants to our list of candidates, after visual examination, will be quasar + star pairs as well as quasar pairs, as either physically associated binary quasars or projected chance alignments. Indeed, 93 of our candidates, the great majority of those with spectroscopic results in the literature, consist of at least one AGN.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that we have typically given a grade of 1 to candidates consisting of object pairs without signs of additional emission, as long as the separation was not too large. This is for two reasons: first, the lensing galaxy may be too faint to detect, which is consistent with the large fraction of known doubles we miss. This fraction would undoubtedly be even higher if we chose to exclude these pairs. Second, because rather than focusing on producing the purest lensed quasar sample, we prefer to include in our sample binary quasars and quasar pairs, which are of interest to the AGN community, for example for studies of quasar triggering (e.g. Hopkins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), and of the small-scale quasar\u2013quasar correlation function (e.g. Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kayo\u00a0&amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515698 id=\"135515698\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Removal of quasar\u2013star pairs using <em>Gaia</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The recent availability of the <em>Gaia</em> mission (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and in particular of its second data release catalogue (DR2; Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>), has resulted in wide application in the latest searches for lensed quasars, as demonstrated by the multitude of recent studies enumerated in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>. Here, we capitalize on the astrometric quantities included in this catalogue in order to further prune our list of candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em> DR2 includes \u223c1.7 billion sources over the whole sky, with a limiting magnitude of <em>G</em> \u223c 21 (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). With a full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of \u22480.1\u2009arcsec (Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), <em>Gaia</em> is effective at deblending close pairs and clusters of objects, down to 0.4\u2009arcsec in DR2 (Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Multi-epoch photometry has enabled the measurement of proper motions and parallaxes for \u223c360 million sources, and the Astrometric Excess Noise (AEN; Koposov, Belokurov\u00a0&amp; Torrealba <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) provides a means of separating compact galaxies from point sources. Colour information (<em>Rp</em> \u2212 <em>Bp</em>) is also available for \u223c1.4 billion sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have cross-matched our candidates with the <em>Gaia</em> DR2 catalogue, in order to identify the counterparts of both <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sources in each candidate (up to four sources, in case of quads). Of the 312 candidates, 307 have detections in <em>Gaia</em>, 291 of these have measured parallaxes and proper motions, and 283 have measured colours. Of their companions (i.e. the secondary component in the pair of each system, or the brightest secondary component in case of quads), the corresponding numbers are 291, 276, and 260.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the proper motion as a classifier, in the form of the proper motion significance defined by Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sqrt{(\\mathrm{ pm}_\\mathrm{ra}/\\sigma _{\\mathrm{ pm}_\\mathrm{ra}})^2+\\mathrm{ pm}_\\mathrm{dec}/\\sigma _{\\mathrm{ pm}\\mathrm{ }_\\mathrm{dec}})^2}$|\u2060</span>, which includes both celestial coordinates, and where \u03c3 stands for the measured uncertainty. We adopt a limiting upper value of 5, which recovers <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }95{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of known lensed quasar images (see fig.\u00a01 in Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). For the parallax \u03d6, we use \u03d6/\u03c3<sub>\u03d6</sub>\u00a0\u2264\u00a04, corresponding to a 4\u03c3 limit, since the distribution of measured parallaxes is well approximated by a Gaussian (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). Finally, we use AEN\u00a0\u2264\u00a04, corresponding to the limit which separates best between lensed quasar images and galaxies, and recovers <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }90{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of the former (see fig.\u00a02 in Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our final classification of the 312 candidates is: 91 surviving candidates yet unconfirmed (1 grade A, 4 grade B, and 86 grade C), 25 confirmed systems (6 quads, 9 doubles,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">9</a></sup> 10 quasar pairs), and 196 rejected candidates. We present our final sample of 91 gravitationally lensed quasar and quasar pair candidates in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, together with our comments based on visual inspection and <em>Gaia</em> measurements. In Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a> we also list the already confirmed candidates, as well as the rejected ones. From these tables it can be seen that the proper motion was the dominant classifier for the overwhelming majority of candidates. Finally, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows that the companions have a similar distribution of <em>Gaia</em> colours with the primary sources, but are typically fainter.</p>                        <a id=\"135515704\" content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a01.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sample of gravitationally lensed quasar candidates and quasar pair candidates identified systematically from <span no <em>Gaia</em> data\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here \u03b1 and \u03b4 are the right ascension and declination of the candidates in the International Celestial Reference System. \u2018#Comp\u2019 refers to the number of components, where we use the number of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sources inside 3\u2009arcsec radius, but revise it based on visual inspection, removing spurious sources and counting additional objects which appear to be part of the system. The measured separation (\u2018Sep.\u2019, in arcsec) is that between the lens candidate point sources or, in case of a quad, the maximum separation between any of the point sources, taken from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or revised as described above. The magnitude is given in <em>i</em> band in the AB system for the brightest resolved component. We quote the <span class=\"monospace\">iMeanPSFMag</span> measurements from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) <span class=\"monospace\">MAG_AUTO</span> in case we had to manually add the brightest component of the system, as described above. We also quote the <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitudes for each system, in the order of increasing separation from the WISE source coordinates. Here \u2018p-l\u2019 stands for \u2018point-like\u2019, whereas \u2018AEN\u2019 (astrometric excess noise), \u2018p\u2019 (parallax), and \u2018pm\u2019 (proper motion) are <em>Gaia</em>-based measurements. We list in this table the alphabetic ranking as gravitationally lensed quasars for all systems with an average grade of 1 and above, based on three human graders, as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. We follow the following convention for the alphabetic ranking: A: average grade &gt;2.5; B: average grade &gt;1.5; C: average grade \u22651. SQLS refers to the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). SDSS spectra were searched inside Data Release 14 (Abolfathi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup>a</sup>After the first draft of this work (arXiv:1803.07175v1), this system was independently announced by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) as a candidate. Our <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> modelling of the observed configuration with an SIE+\u03b3 mass profile results in a perfect fit, but the model is underconstrained because the lensing galaxy is not detected.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA; similar colour p-l; both components have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>192808+553219\u00a0</td><td>292.032689\u00a0</td><td>55.538539\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>18.05\u00a0</td><td>2.7\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>19.00, 18.32; similar colour p-l; both have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>222108+214518\u00a0</td><td>335.283056\u00a0</td><td>21.754907\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>17.34\u00a0</td><td>3.5\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>17.57; different colour p-l; only the main component has <em>Gaia</em> data, negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>230339+345343\u00a0</td><td>345.91142\u00a0</td><td>34.89518\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>18.36\u00a0</td><td>7.1\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>18.65, 18.98; similar colour p-l; both have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>232223+375439\u00a0</td><td>350.595174\u00a0</td><td>37.910703\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>19.23\u00a0</td><td>2.2\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>19.87, 20.81; p-l; both have negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>232449\u2212122555\u00a0</td><td>351.205773\u00a0</td><td>\u221212.432025\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>18.93\u00a0</td><td>1.8\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>19.25; p-l; only one component has <em>Gaia</em>data, negligible AEN, p, and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>233525+184309\u00a0</td><td>353.85286\u00a0</td><td>18.71912\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>19.31\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>red components; no <em>Gaia</em> data\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here \u03b1 and \u03b4 are the right ascension and declination of the candidates in the International Celestial Reference System. \u2018#Comp\u2019 refers to the number of components, where we use the number of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> sources inside 3\u2009arcsec radius, but revise it based on visual inspection, removing spurious sources and counting additional objects which appear to be part of the system. The measured separation (\u2018Sep.\u2019, in arcsec) is that between the lens candidate point sources or, in case of a quad, the maximum separation between any of the point sources, taken from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or revised as described above. The magnitude is given in <em>i</em> band in the AB system for the brightest resolved component. We quote the <span class=\"monospace\">iMeanPSFMag</span> measurements from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue, or the <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) <span class=\"monospace\">MAG_AUTO</span> in case we had to manually add the brightest component of the system, as described above. We also quote the <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitudes for each system, in the order of increasing separation from the WISE source coordinates. Here \u2018p-l\u2019 stands for \u2018point-like\u2019, whereas \u2018AEN\u2019 (astrometric excess noise), \u2018p\u2019 (parallax), and \u2018pm\u2019 (proper motion) are <em>Gaia</em>-based measurements. We list in this table the alphabetic ranking as gravitationally lensed quasars for all systems with an average grade of 1 and above, based on three human graders, as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. We follow the following convention for the alphabetic ranking: A: average grade &gt;2.5; B: average grade &gt;1.5; C: average grade \u22651. SQLS refers to the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). SDSS spectra were searched inside Data Release 14 (Abolfathi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup>a</sup>After the first draft of this work (arXiv:1803.07175v1), this system was independently announced by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) as a candidate. Our <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> modelling of the observed configuration with an SIE+\u03b3 mass profile results in a perfect fit, but the model is underconstrained because the lensing galaxy is not detected.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515705\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515706 id=\"135515706\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Expected sample purity</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the expected completeness, we also wish to estimate the purity of our sample, defined as the ratio of (number of gravitational lenses +quasar pairs)/(total number of sources in the sample). First, we perform a simple exercise where we estimate this number focusing only on the quasar pairs, and comparing the density of sources in a catalogue of point sources, and one of AGN. The idea is to estimate how many of the candidate source companions are expected to be AGN, as opposed to stars. We present the details of the computation in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec7\">A</a>. We arrive at a result of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim } 4{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected purity can be computed more directly using the subsample of candidates for which spectroscopic data are available in the literature. Out of 33 candidates which survive the <em>Gaia</em>-based cut and which can be either confirmed or ruled out based on the literature, 9 are doubles, 10 are quasar pairs, 6 are quads, and 8 are galaxy + other, star + other, or star + QSO (here \u2018other\u2019 stands for non-QSO). For systems with <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020 for all components (the limit at which <em>Gaia</em> is still relatively complete), these numbers are 7, 9, 5, and 5, respectively. This means that for <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020, if we ignore the quads (there is only one quad candidate in our final sample, and these systems are much easier to identify visually, leading to different selection), the purity for quasar pairs is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$9/21\\approx 43{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, and for doubles + quasar pairs it is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16/21\\approx 76{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Of course, care must be taken in interpreting this result, as the spectroscopic selection of these sources compiled from the literature is unknown.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">How can the discrepant results of the two methods be reconciled? This is likely due to the known clustering of quasars, which leads to a significant enhancement of small-separation quasar\u2013quasar pairs over expectations from uniform spatial distribution assumptions and catalogue density comparisons, and it means that the number we computed with that method must be interpreted as a lower limit. The quasar\u2013quasar correlation function is predicted to produce an enhanced by a factor of \u223c100 on small angular scales corresponding to quasar pairs (e.g. Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>, and references therein). For our 91 candidates and confirmed quasar pairs we measure a median separation of 2.4\u2009arcsec, with a standard deviation of 0.53\u2009arcsec (after removing four systems with separation &gt;4.5\u2009arcsec). Kayo\u00a0&amp; Oguri (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) do indeed estimate an increase by a factor of \u223c200 in the number of quasar pairs with separation typical for our candidates (physical scale \u223c20\u00a0kpc), over the random expectation, based on a sample of binary quasars obtained as a byproduct of a search for gravitationally lensed quasars (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). This is more than enough to explain the discrepancy. In fact, multiplying this number with the fraction of AGN to point sources found in our simple exercise suggests a purity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }90{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. This may be an overestimate, as there is a known discrepancy between the large number of predicted binary quasars (e.g. Hopkins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and the smaller number of discovered ones (e.g. Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We adopt as our best estimate of the purity the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }76{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> value measured above for quasar pairs + doubles, although we caution that this estimate might be biased due to the unknown spectroscopic selection, and applies only to <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020. If we remove the magnitude cut, based on the spectroscopic sample, this becomes <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }70{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the following sections, we focus on modelling the imaging and spectroscopic data of 2M1134\u22122103.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515711 id=\"135515711\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 2M1134\u22122103: IMAGING DATA REDUCTION AND MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">2M1134\u22122103 consists of four point-like lensed quasar images and a lensing galaxy (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The lensing galaxy 2M1134\u22122103 can be convincingly identified in the near-infrared imaging (particularly <em>Ks</em>-band) from the VISTA Hemisphere Survey (hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a>; McMahon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, see also Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). While the relative astrometry of the quasar images, measured from VST-ATLAS (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), is reported in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, the VST-ATLAS data are not publicly accessible. Furthermore, the VST-ATLAS data have better seeing (0.72\u2009arcsec) but the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data are deeper. Therefore, we make use of archival <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data in our analysis. The processing of the archival <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data (Flewelling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) is described in Magnier et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), and includes removal of the instrumental signature, image coaddition, as well as photometric and astrometric calibration (Magnier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>). Here, we model the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>,<em>grizy</em> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a>,<em>YJKs</em> images independently of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"135515713\" scrollto-destination=\"135515713\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a02.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=0iLR~dG395eJqDaQEpBxaLknRPFyTuvH4eNMJjLx3XM4XIFbWORHTM6W5gbyiGzmFfd1RM-elAz5X5ucozL6sOTo8Ixo4sYKFms64JYEPnLBVjNj3gVRG~kj2sAAxHp6gx6s0tn~W-uhb7h~pU63LNM3C1QM7-DmqMDnIQ7lJ6I4GRC5D0Jm1DLnNZuGgavwZh1VfyKYIKDLwLpKrmIKcHiVW~18IdE1DO7ALDyXUqrFjJ~JoKdi6bUOZgleTnEaqRc3vV8yPoae2abo1Oehet0ilxkf6Q8sdl62HHS1X83WNLjeAXPBi5v9jDCGpEGUG3HYyyTxm-ZI13CMi1cL8Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper left: Colour composite (VHS-YJKs) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. Lower left: The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with hostlens, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. Right: Colour composite (riz) using PS1 data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515713/stz1142fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515713\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=dKX1sYZgDjDB0QpcTwhX3z0iOI~VPSd0Ye9vAg8pyTKFXxQ5pkx8SBj5sq9jNVi5UOhG1dnnzFL~vLOVdpljFdptNMAh4be4c2dwUs0QjvaS2h3towzUyESnsF5TdJp3dALaH5GmVrYHXCedpzQ-WYizoAJdHQOeDZ0VN88eAkmDHtex9sybRSWQWox2bSM7CqCc0~5XOAkYmqLL67Rb1rRdIt01hG9bOtPA5ivJtF9QWv-NhXNCOFDTFD52toN1UBNRZ0T26SwNBo0rlobzqICOv0~C8XJtjGfraHuxDSn6uWI0Sx1pj3WiCZHtI9z0WL-Kdg98~9uk0Tt-4M6zmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515713&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Upper left:</em> Colour composite (VHS-<em>YJKs</em>) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. <em>Lower left:</em> The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. <em>Right:</em> Colour composite (<em>riz</em>) using <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a02.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=0iLR~dG395eJqDaQEpBxaLknRPFyTuvH4eNMJjLx3XM4XIFbWORHTM6W5gbyiGzmFfd1RM-elAz5X5ucozL6sOTo8Ixo4sYKFms64JYEPnLBVjNj3gVRG~kj2sAAxHp6gx6s0tn~W-uhb7h~pU63LNM3C1QM7-DmqMDnIQ7lJ6I4GRC5D0Jm1DLnNZuGgavwZh1VfyKYIKDLwLpKrmIKcHiVW~18IdE1DO7ALDyXUqrFjJ~JoKdi6bUOZgleTnEaqRc3vV8yPoae2abo1Oehet0ilxkf6Q8sdl62HHS1X83WNLjeAXPBi5v9jDCGpEGUG3HYyyTxm-ZI13CMi1cL8Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper left: Colour composite (VHS-YJKs) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. Lower left: The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with hostlens, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. Right: Colour composite (riz) using PS1 data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515713/stz1142fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515713\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=dKX1sYZgDjDB0QpcTwhX3z0iOI~VPSd0Ye9vAg8pyTKFXxQ5pkx8SBj5sq9jNVi5UOhG1dnnzFL~vLOVdpljFdptNMAh4be4c2dwUs0QjvaS2h3towzUyESnsF5TdJp3dALaH5GmVrYHXCedpzQ-WYizoAJdHQOeDZ0VN88eAkmDHtex9sybRSWQWox2bSM7CqCc0~5XOAkYmqLL67Rb1rRdIt01hG9bOtPA5ivJtF9QWv-NhXNCOFDTFD52toN1UBNRZ0T26SwNBo0rlobzqICOv0~C8XJtjGfraHuxDSn6uWI0Sx1pj3WiCZHtI9z0WL-Kdg98~9uk0Tt-4M6zmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515713&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Upper left:</em> Colour composite (VHS-<em>YJKs</em>) of 2M1134\u22122103 showing the four lensed quasar images (A, B, C, and D). Image is 10\u2009arcsec on the side. <em>Lower left:</em> The same colour composite, after subtracting the four quasar images with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>, shows the presence of a lensing galaxy G. <em>Right:</em> Colour composite (<em>riz</em>) using <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data shows the immediate environment of the lens system, which is located at the centre. Image is 60\u2009arcsec on the side. All images are oriented such that North is up and East is to the left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For our detailed modelling of 2M1134\u22122103 we downloaded from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> archives 180\u00a0\u00d7 180\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup> cut-outs around the system in all available filters, large enough to contain stars to model the PSF and to improve the image orientation. We subtracted the sky background from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> images using <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), and resampled all images with <span class=\"small-caps\">swarp</span> (Bertin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) to a common orientation. We measured final pixel scales with <span class=\"small-caps\">scamp</span> (Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We model the system with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span> (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span> models an arbitrary number of point-like and extended sources using a common point spread function (PSF), either specified by the user from nearby stars, or fitted to the data as a sum of two concentric Moffat (Moffat <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1969</a>) profiles. We find that modelling the quasar images using nearby stars as PSFs results in significant residuals, which could affect the image flux measurements and the characterization of the lensing galaxy. We therefore model the data using an analytical PSF fitted to the data. To remove residuals still remaining at the centres of the three bright quasar images in the <em>rizYJKs</em> bands, we use the PSF reconstruction technique described in Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), with the best-fitting analytical PSF as a starting point. This technique reconstructs the PSF iteratively, on a grid of pixels, under the assumption that the PSF does not vary across the quasar images. The remaining residuals at the location of the quasar images are small, as can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"135515716\" scrollto-destination=\"135515716\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a03.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=gdK7nh3iA-PZWJRWvw5QDeKkoWciVolgjZvyXXmUXbUpq9Zp9LlYgPJbJAv0G2KcQrKKlWw~94iefBwUlRD7ypKV~2s9bZf8SM4GPX~LK0gFSmGPaa356HvQE-xSWsxAzQlshLNWMyE0pKZ~c2ULgvgWpxEgvIdgxu0kP3t5QjM03WkubELQrF7sxzqUbIFXTlQjoBsQnQbXybXgA1Pw~BeTIoarHDUnc149Rh~Ly1ik~aA1bbo8Sap8TgvUuyL8rU~149zW8U1Hcisrn9Wfd6Jj~VUQv8Rk~4WHn-Zs5j5j2Pgs3NWWbURy3AsMdjSWsISYl928jMoV3XAfugjrgA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with hostlens. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec2. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in JKs) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the r and i bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a05).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515716/stz1142fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515716\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=k2mmeKiMU8GbX~MXSPUwLQNDSc~As8RhreeHtxwTq2OuC4sX7gxiMr4n4J3DgWKRBNapSB0yLKfCP8KE0LL0PpxZL9iT3TjxE3Kmingvsti99cS5g07n0rmWkBtzhHUlTzrhVZrFDWHjZbBHF8vcuNV-3i5hqddsONQwM9HxYYQr0r7Tmj3q5AnY1v~vlbh0nx8gkOuI8UyKCYHY07evHeTIgzK~Rw5iCfW463UxE4VgMV2fon4ybiVpYgj-z~c7nrpSYp1-wwh2wcn7yHaZPsaxR~JRm6VKm65V~s9F0s1moHxvO~MN1A4w-l0paUMswPECMTLh0q2bvugRwwbcHg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515716&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup>. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in <em>JKs</em>) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a03.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=gdK7nh3iA-PZWJRWvw5QDeKkoWciVolgjZvyXXmUXbUpq9Zp9LlYgPJbJAv0G2KcQrKKlWw~94iefBwUlRD7ypKV~2s9bZf8SM4GPX~LK0gFSmGPaa356HvQE-xSWsxAzQlshLNWMyE0pKZ~c2ULgvgWpxEgvIdgxu0kP3t5QjM03WkubELQrF7sxzqUbIFXTlQjoBsQnQbXybXgA1Pw~BeTIoarHDUnc149Rh~Ly1ik~aA1bbo8Sap8TgvUuyL8rU~149zW8U1Hcisrn9Wfd6Jj~VUQv8Rk~4WHn-Zs5j5j2Pgs3NWWbURy3AsMdjSWsISYl928jMoV3XAfugjrgA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with hostlens. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec2. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in JKs) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the r and i bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a05).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515716/stz1142fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515716\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=k2mmeKiMU8GbX~MXSPUwLQNDSc~As8RhreeHtxwTq2OuC4sX7gxiMr4n4J3DgWKRBNapSB0yLKfCP8KE0LL0PpxZL9iT3TjxE3Kmingvsti99cS5g07n0rmWkBtzhHUlTzrhVZrFDWHjZbBHF8vcuNV-3i5hqddsONQwM9HxYYQr0r7Tmj3q5AnY1v~vlbh0nx8gkOuI8UyKCYHY07evHeTIgzK~Rw5iCfW463UxE4VgMV2fon4ybiVpYgj-z~c7nrpSYp1-wwh2wcn7yHaZPsaxR~JRm6VKm65V~s9F0s1moHxvO~MN1A4w-l0paUMswPECMTLh0q2bvugRwwbcHg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515716&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residuals after morphological modelling of imaging data with <span class=\"small-caps\">hostlens</span>. The size of the cutouts is 15\u00a0\u00d7 15\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup>. The images were divided by the associated noise maps, then smoothed with a 3-pixel Gaussian, to enhance structure. The positions of the components that were modelled in each band (A, B, C, D, as well as G in <em>JKs</em>) are marked with star symbols. Object GX to the south-east of the lens, conspicuous in the <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands, is left unmodelled (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> data we do not detect any sign of the lensing galaxy, which however stands out in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a>,<em>J</em> and <em>Ks</em> images. We model its light profile in these bands simultaneously with the quasar images, using a de Vaucouleurs (de Vaucouleurs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1948</a>) profile commonly used for early-type lensing galaxies. A circular profile fits the emission from the lensing galaxy well, without leaving noticeable residuals. Using a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach, we find that the lensing galaxy flux is highly degenerate with the effective radius of the de Vaucouleurs profile, and is therefore unreliable.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to perform gravitational lens modelling of 2M1134\u22122103 we need to estimate reliable relative astrometry for the quasar images and the lensing galaxy. For the three brightest quasar images we take the mean and scatter between the measured relative astrometry in different filters (excluding <em>g</em> band, where the seeing is significantly larger, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), whereas for the lensing galaxy and the faint counterimage D, we only use the <em>J</em> and <em>Ks</em> filters. Indeed, the separation between the brighter images (A, B, and C) and the fainter counterimage (D) decreases slightly with increasing wavelength in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> images, because of the progressively increasing flux contribution from the red lensing galaxy. We report our measured astrometry and photometry in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Our astrometry is consistent with the one presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a> within our 2\u03c3 uncertainties.</p>                        <a id=\"135515719\" scrollto-destination=\"135515719\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a02.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry and absolute photometry of 2M1134\u22122103.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Filter (lim. mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\"
