class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry is determined by using information from multiple filters (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>). The units are in arcsec and the sign convention is positive from E to W (<em>x</em>-axis) and from S to N (<em>y</em>-axis). The ICRS position of image A in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue is (J2000.0) 11:34:40.588\u201321:03:23.06. Magnitudes are in the AB (<em>grizy</em>) and Vega (<em>YJKs</em>) systems, and are corrected for Galactic extinction following Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The 1\u03c3 limiting magnitudes are computed in 2\u2009arcsec-radius blank sky apertures around the system. The errors on magnitudes are those from MCMC, with the minimum uncertainty boosted to 0.005 mag, and do not include zero-point or PSF uncertainties. The magnitudes of G and GX (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) should be considered unreliable, as in order for the fit to converge, the effective radius was fixed to &lt;1\u00a0pixel.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515719\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div (<em>x</em>-axis)\u00a0</td><td>0.000\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.000\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.733\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>1.944\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>1.262\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.014\u00a0</td><td>0.74\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>all (23.6)\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>16.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>18.49\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>y</em> (22.6)\u00a0</td><td>16.79\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>16.72\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>16.70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>18.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Y</em> (22.2)\u00a0</td><td>16.08\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008\u00a0</td><td>15.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.007\u00a0</td><td>16.02\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.007\u00a0</td><td>17.57\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.016\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>J</em> (21.4)\u00a0</td><td>15.92\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>15.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005\u00a0</td><td>17.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.012\u00a0</td><td>[19.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Ks</em> (20.1)\u00a0</td><td>15.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.006\u00a0</td><td>15.19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.009\u00a0</td><td>16.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.027\u00a0</td><td>[17.33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relative astrometry is determined by using information from multiple filters (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>). The units are in arcsec and the sign convention is positive from E to W (<em>x</em>-axis) and from S to N (<em>y</em>-axis). The ICRS position of image A in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> catalogue is (J2000.0) 11:34:40.588\u201321:03:23.06. Magnitudes are in the AB (<em>grizy</em>) and Vega (<em>YJKs</em>) systems, and are corrected for Galactic extinction following Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The 1\u03c3 limiting magnitudes are computed in 2\u2009arcsec-radius blank sky apertures around the system. The errors on magnitudes are those from MCMC, with the minimum uncertainty boosted to 0.005 mag, and do not include zero-point or PSF uncertainties. The magnitudes of G and GX (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) should be considered unreliable, as in order for the fit to converge, the effective radius was fixed to &lt;1\u00a0pixel.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515719\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515720 id=\"135515720\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 2M1134\u22122103: KECK SPECTROSCOPY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The 2M1134\u22122103 lens system was observed with the Echellette Spectrograph and Imager (ESI; Sheinis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) on the night of 2017 November 18 <span class=\"small-caps\">ut</span> (program number 2017B_U110). The observations utilized a slit with a width of 1\u2009arcsec and the cross-dispersed Echellette mode of the spectrograph, which provides a constant dispersion of roughly 11.5\u00a0km\u00a0sec<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pix<sup>\u22121</sup> over a wavelength range of approximately 3900\u201311\u2009000\u00a0\u00c5. Here, we follow the nomenclature of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>. Two slit position angles were used, one oriented at +46.7\u2009deg (N through E) in order to go across lensed images B and C (henceforth the \u2018BC slit\u2019) and one oriented at \u221242.3\u2009deg to cover images A and D (the \u2018AD slit\u2019). We obtained three 600\u00a0s exposures through the BC slit and four 600\u00a0s exposures through the AD slit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We calibrated the data using a custom pipeline written in <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>. The pipeline does a flat-field correction, rectifies the two-dimensional spectra, does the wavelength calibration using both arc lamp and night sky emission lines, and subtracts the sky emission. The calibrated data for both slits are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. In the AD slit, the two-dimensional spectra show one bright trace that is heavily blended with a much fainter trace, while the BC slit shows three clearly separated traces. We identify the three traces in the BC slit with components B, A+D+G, and C in the imaging data. Based on the imaging, we expect that the emission from image A completely dominates the central trace.</p>                        <a id=\"135515723\" scrollto-destination=\"135515723\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=XAiLJio2tUDAnjVevePbGPIYw4aygOI~1ACRmbZmzRWAEAfEpbdh-0fetHfw8lolx2RdQunYe5gC95XsRt3MMp0v0qSQV8kJgOEEuW1BxyYnotlyQyF1HetNLnEVyJLTJ8qnV8OXss5EceOOkPPX~~I2SYv3gVqgFKGi1Bu-Qs-OuoI2eytWyqC5upY9BBG~0YdtxafsvBm0c~BZIQKWo7Oyi6r1mdcI5nJhBqVLRC~AsuizWlnGxG4PG~xik0IDWUtYp8SUrhly3-CXPdyRtMvvdDopRWDXI5WEWU0V0XI4UbUnvGkc3hdb~OzgxTKycSSqj3XeyWyYec2Sus3XbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515723/stz1142fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515723\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=GNApqDcJf2NGQ0OmkfVHBQgD-fFlMW5y5Nm4IX4oRXpxafWdcpa2Y8Ub4hCuAw-pyJ8Kt~Nul0efSRRrbnFNa-OiMqpycob9Z7Who38M2CUw5guqdSzWyWXILnF1-ir~q1KZKOlFgSgh54N5gurM5RiffDVOjg7Y8Q8oVjF1JhLIxQEsCX2CfoKmLx44NTEp~tOmDiMpc83adtO6rFP4k0IE4XVR8OqbSxhtePqWaEhPe-qbSK-r8aejC01AL2txfQ9sClhZ3KdW~IPlAbsFRhyAtlm6D~NsXTFomC6xZpL2D465o3wNtV5xTPb9NB4mtkFSe4IBpdEfJbkEpO81wA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515723&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=XAiLJio2tUDAnjVevePbGPIYw4aygOI~1ACRmbZmzRWAEAfEpbdh-0fetHfw8lolx2RdQunYe5gC95XsRt3MMp0v0qSQV8kJgOEEuW1BxyYnotlyQyF1HetNLnEVyJLTJ8qnV8OXss5EceOOkPPX~~I2SYv3gVqgFKGi1Bu-Qs-OuoI2eytWyqC5upY9BBG~0YdtxafsvBm0c~BZIQKWo7Oyi6r1mdcI5nJhBqVLRC~AsuizWlnGxG4PG~xik0IDWUtYp8SUrhly3-CXPdyRtMvvdDopRWDXI5WEWU0V0XI4UbUnvGkc3hdb~OzgxTKycSSqj3XeyWyYec2Sus3XbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515723/stz1142fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515723\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=GNApqDcJf2NGQ0OmkfVHBQgD-fFlMW5y5Nm4IX4oRXpxafWdcpa2Y8Ub4hCuAw-pyJ8Kt~Nul0efSRRrbnFNa-OiMqpycob9Z7Who38M2CUw5guqdSzWyWXILnF1-ir~q1KZKOlFgSgh54N5gurM5RiffDVOjg7Y8Q8oVjF1JhLIxQEsCX2CfoKmLx44NTEp~tOmDiMpc83adtO6rFP4k0IE4XVR8OqbSxhtePqWaEhPe-qbSK-r8aejC01AL2txfQ9sClhZ3KdW~IPlAbsFRhyAtlm6D~NsXTFomC6xZpL2D465o3wNtV5xTPb9NB4mtkFSe4IBpdEfJbkEpO81wA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515723&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of the calibrated and sky-subtracted spectra obtained with Keck/ESI of 2M1134\u22122103. Data are from the AD slit (top) and the BC slit (bottom), with spectra showing a portion of the fifth of ten spectral orders recorded by the spectrograph.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We extracted one-dimensional spectra from the exposures on both slits using a second Python pipeline that extracts the spectra from each spectral order, applies a response correction based on observations of a spectrophotometric standard, in this case Feige\u00a0110, and finally combines the data from each of the 10 spectral orders into one final spectrum. For the AD slit, we only extracted one aperture that we identify with a blend of A, D, and G, while for the BC slit we extracted separate apertures corresponding to B, A+D+G, and C. Note that the AD slit may very well contain significant scattered light from images B and C. The extracted spectra are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and all show clear broad emission lines that, furthermore, are indicative of quasars at a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>src</sub> \u223c 2.77. Thus, the ESI spectra are fully consistent with the interpretation of 2M1134\u22122103 as a quad lensed quasar. An exact value of the source redshift is difficult to obtain due to the fact that the peaks of the lines used for redshift determination are affected by absorption systems (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>; also e.g. Lee <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The measured redshift is smaller than the <em>z</em> \u223c 3.5 estimate in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> colours.</p>                        <a id=\"135515725\" scrollto-destination=\"135515725\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=ZPRChnIFMMwiXhwEvyNGZmhZTR4NpCZg8RJSjMtWvXEA8Jl4M69idI4c0SWFu0Wn8JcqgwPAGynaKSZLtCoB8iDaswCUZhq97wR5dOfxE~o3sdvIWgVRn1p8CFTl15gGQGkZAaZZO9AbxVdz2AtAiObOg5Qzo~X7zfH6aSVLJ~R3nGGLMzreD2O4eSCtqGz4FZDPuDDnL~Ts3aVmC~gIp~IcoP9ejjuMJBeL0itMtkLxWvWBeLSGrsUo39UkIzFKcGbiLH0bPc1J5RG2Wq6KRoBAxF2sHcCnBTfoKx5~I9hvscL3xkD96Pz911HKHe68zAmZQVpVCcd7zbeJU5N43A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Combined light from lensed images A and D, plus any emission from the lensing galaxy is visible in the spectrum extracted from the AD slit (green) as well as that from the BC slit (dark blue) in the top panel. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a04). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515725/stz1142fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515725\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=nWgSkQvxPThCJW~ERoqRW4c6XfzPt1xOzNFeSQ-6CD2oT29DqlCctQlHpqXUsdtI6GR37Ph5Zbkopd7Y7kIZ5kmsu~M~FzTyZJ9XnA4mVCNary8AFOyBOjqkh~0D83uZie4hzj4UnV3RIzdV~Cx54i-QX2PfCkY~1RWNnBq80WABTpah-11tx2UN1d9K-vQDcI26hJqNjWNvvaiqM64zegU4SpRXsSEQ7Hn0syVrjYf1bcbEodCK5l-TaeSnyamokvgyEJcTXcY7XP1aUp0-VZAjTtPG3NSqe7sYKKPqIB1Vr8IpiELPSbkQWjHDJKXWVhBwpz5aupqzw6KPbJFDPg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515725&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Combined light from lensed images A and D, plus any emission from the lensing galaxy is visible in the spectrum extracted from the AD slit (green) as well as that from the BC slit (dark blue) in the top panel. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=ZPRChnIFMMwiXhwEvyNGZmhZTR4NpCZg8RJSjMtWvXEA8Jl4M69idI4c0SWFu0Wn8JcqgwPAGynaKSZLtCoB8iDaswCUZhq97wR5dOfxE~o3sdvIWgVRn1p8CFTl15gGQGkZAaZZO9AbxVdz2AtAiObOg5Qzo~X7zfH6aSVLJ~R3nGGLMzreD2O4eSCtqGz4FZDPuDDnL~Ts3aVmC~gIp~IcoP9ejjuMJBeL0itMtkLxWvWBeLSGrsUo39UkIzFKcGbiLH0bPc1J5RG2Wq6KRoBAxF2sHcCnBTfoKx5~I9hvscL3xkD96Pz911HKHe68zAmZQVpVCcd7zbeJU5N43A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a04). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515725/stz1142fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515725\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=nWgSkQvxPThCJW~ERoqRW4c6XfzPt1xOzNFeSQ-6CD2oT29DqlCctQlHpqXUsdtI6GR37Ph5Zbkopd7Y7kIZ5kmsu~M~FzTyZJ9XnA4mVCNary8AFOyBOjqkh~0D83uZie4hzj4UnV3RIzdV~Cx54i-QX2PfCkY~1RWNnBq80WABTpah-11tx2UN1d9K-vQDcI26hJqNjWNvvaiqM64zegU4SpRXsSEQ7Hn0syVrjYf1bcbEodCK5l-TaeSnyamokvgyEJcTXcY7XP1aUp0-VZAjTtPG3NSqe7sYKKPqIB1Vr8IpiELPSbkQWjHDJKXWVhBwpz5aupqzw6KPbJFDPg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515725&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ESI spectra of 2M1134\u22122103. Combined light from lensed images A and D, plus any emission from the lensing galaxy is visible in the spectrum extracted from the AD slit (green) as well as that from the BC slit (dark blue) in the top panel. Spectra of images B (middle) and C (bottom) are extracted from the BC slit. The rms noise of each spectrum is plotted in red. Identified emission and absorption systems are labelled (see further explanation in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>). The wide absorption doublet at \u223c7650 \u00c5 is telluric. The spectra were smoothed using a 3-pixel boxcar with inverse-variance weighting.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the broad emission lines, all of the spectra show a number of absorption lines. In the range 5000\u20137500\u2009\u00c5, these correspond to absorption features of Fe and Mg, and are consistent with two separate absorption systems at <em>z</em><sub>abs,1</sub>\u00a0= 1.554 and <em>z</em><sub>abs,2</sub>\u00a0= 1.481. The first system has stronger lines in the A+D+G and B spectra, while the second is stronger in the image C spectrum. Although it is possible that these systems may be associated with the primary lensing galaxy, the narrowness of the lines makes this interpretation unlikely. A much stronger indication of the lensing galaxy would be the detection of stellar absorption lines, such as the Ca\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> H and K lines, with widths consistent with the velocity dispersions of &gt;100\u00a0km s<sup>\u22121</sup> expected for a massive lensing galaxy. If these corresponded to the redshifts of the absorption features mentioned above, they would be observed at wavelengths longer than the ones plotted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, where we have extracted robust spectra.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515727 id=\"135515727\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 2M1134\u22122103: G\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ravitational lens modelling</span></h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We perform gravitational lens mass modelling of 2M1134\u22122103 with <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), using the observed relative positions of the quasar images and the lensing galaxy as constraints. We do not impose constraints based on the flux ratios, as these might be affected by microlensing, extinction, and intrinsic variability (e.g. Yonehara, Hirashita\u00a0&amp; Richter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). However, we analyse the observed flux ratios under the assumptions that they are dominated by extinction, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We start with the same mass model used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, a singular isothermal sphere with external shear (SIS+\u03b3). This model has \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 7.5/3 (where d.o.f. stands for degrees of freedom), most of which is due to the difference between the measured and predicted position of image D relative to the lens G. We recover the results of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a>, in particular that an unusually large shear of \u223c0.34 at 44\u00a0deg W of N is required to fit this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Secondly, we fit a model which allows for mass ellipticity, SIE+\u03b3. Indeed, quads have enough constraints to disentangle internal and external sources of shear, and our fit shows a dramatic improvement to \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 0.1/1. This model requires a shear of \u223c0.39, slightly larger than before, and a mass axial ratio of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.80^{+0.10}_{-0.18}$|\u2060</span>, with the long axis at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$37^{+5}_{-13}$|</span> deg E of N, almost perpendicular to that of the shear. While our imaging data does not have sufficient resolution to fit an elliptical light profile to the lensing galaxy, studies of quads show that the mass and light profiles of lensing galaxies are typically aligned (e.g. Keeton, Kochanek\u00a0&amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We note that Rusu\u00a0&amp; Lemon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) modelled a different quad, GraL\u00a0J1817+2729, in a cross-like configuration, and showed that while an SIE+\u03b3 model required large shear and large ellipticity, with the long axis perpendicular to the shear, similar to the present case, a Sersic+SIS+\u03b3 model, where the Sersic component stands for the baryonic matter in the disc of the lensing galaxy, significantly diminishes the required shear, and changes its orientation. We attempted to fit such as model here, but it behaves equivalently to our SIE+\u03b3 model, requiring similar orientation and large shear. It appears that the highly stretched, diamond-like configuration, cannot be explained by internal sources of shear.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As both the SIS+\u03b3 and SIE+\u03b3 models are consistent in their requirement of large external shear, we look for potential sources of shear from the surrounding environment. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> we display a 60\u00a0\u00d7 60\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup> colour composite image around 2M1134\u22122103, which clearly shows a group of red galaxies in the upper right corner, the brightest of which is a <em>i</em>\u00a0= 19.32 galaxy located at \u03b1\u00a0= 173.6620, \u03b4\u00a0= \u221221.0502, 30\u2009arcsec from the quad, in the direction of 45\u00a0deg W of N. The <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> colours of this galaxy imply a photometric redshift of 0.70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09, estimated with <span class=\"monospace\">BPZ</span> (Ben\u00edtez <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). The existence of the galaxy group at this location implies that it is responsible for part of the measured shear. However this is unlikely to be the complete picture, as an SIS profile at the location of this galaxy would require a very large velocity dispersion \u22731100\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> to produce the measured shear, depending on the redshift of the lensing galaxy in 2M1134\u22122103.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> reveals another clue, closer to 2M1134\u22122103. After subtracting the quasar images, an additional component is detected in filters <em>r</em> and <em>i</em>, 4.16\u2009arcsec from image A, also in the direction of the shear, towards south-east. It is unclear whether this new component, which we name GX, is a galaxy or a star, as it is too faint (<em>i</em> \u223c 21.75) to constrain its morphology. Under the assumption that it is a galaxy, its colours suggest a redshift lower than the one of the lensing galaxy, which is only detected in the near-infrared <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> filters. We incorporate GX into a third lensing model, in order to estimate its effect on the external shear. As we do not know the redshifts for either G or GX, we consider the simplest case in which G and GX are modelled as SIS of equal strength, at the same redshift. This model is expected to be an upper limit to the contribution of GX to the lensing configuration, as GX is likely a lower redshift, low-mass galaxy. We obtain a good fit with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 2.3/3, and a residual external shear of \u223c0.19, oriented as before. In this model, the two lenses are located \u223c4 Einstein radii apart, in units of the Einstein radius of G. Our model shows that GX can explain a significant fraction of the shear we measured in our initial SIS+\u03b3 model. We expect that in reality most of the measured shear is an interplay between the effects of GX and the nearby group. In our model incorporating GX, the nearby group would still require a velocity dispersion of \u223c800\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> to account for the remaining shear, which would imply \u227350 group/cluster members (e.g. Berlind et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). While we do not see more than \u223c3 possible galaxy members in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> image, this is not an argument against the existence of this structure, as the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> images are shallow. Indeed, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a> images of the system RX\u00a0J0911+05 reveal only \u223c5 galaxies part of a spectroscopically confirmed cluster with at least 24 members at a similar redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.769, with velocity dispersion \u223c800\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Kneib, Cohen\u00a0&amp; Hjorth <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), giving rise to a very large shear \u22730.3 (Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that another lensed system with a remarkably similar diamond-like configuration has recently been discovered (Bettoni et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) close to a galaxy cluster, also with a large measured shear of 0.31 and a nearby galaxy in the direction of the shear. Finally, we note that highly sheared quadruple lens systems are not unexpected, and are a consequence of the tendency of elliptical galaxies, which constitute most of the lensing galaxies, to reside in overdense regions with high shear (e.g. Holder\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). We conclude that the large shear values we measure do not therefore point out to a problem with our mass models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the analysis above we did not assume particular values of source and lens redshifts, except when we estimated the velocity dispersion of the galaxy group at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.7. The flux ratios are also insensitive to the choice of redshifts, however the estimated time delays depend on them. To estimate the time delays, which are of interest to cosmography studies (e.g. Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we use the source quasar redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0= 2.77 measured from spectroscopy, and the lens redshift limits we infer below in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>, <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.45\u00a0\u2212\u00a01.5. For <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.45 and the SIS+\u03b3 model, the estimated time delays are \u0394CB \u223c 7\u00a0d, \u0394CA \u223c 30\u00a0d, and \u0394CD \u223c 55\u00a0d. The order of the image time arrival is the same in all three models, with image C leading. We summarize the main parameters of the mass models we employed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, along with the corresponding time delays.</p>                        <a id=\"135515735\" scrollto-destination=\"135515735\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf7\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here <em>z</em> is the lens redshift, \u03c3 is the lens velocity dispersion, <em>e</em> and \u03b3 are the lens ellipticity and shear, respectively, and \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> and \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub> are their orientations (W of N). The time delays (last column) are in units of days.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515735\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a03.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the best-fitting parameter values of the lensing mass models, and the predicted time delays.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3 (km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>e</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CB<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CD<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>243.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>30.5\u00a0</td><td>6.8\u00a0</td><td>54.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>384.1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>196.6\u00a0</td><td>43.9\u00a0</td><td>353.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>242.1\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>24.7\u00a0</td><td>6.3\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>382.6\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>159.0\u00a0</td><td>40.3\u00a0</td><td>281.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>233.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>33.9\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>44.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>363.4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>225.9\u00a0</td><td>49.3\u00a0</td><td>263.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3 (km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>e</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CB<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394CD<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>243.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>30.5\u00a0</td><td>6.8\u00a0</td><td>54.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>384.1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td><td>196.6\u00a0</td><td>43.9\u00a0</td><td>353.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>242.1\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>24.7\u00a0</td><td>6.3\u00a0</td><td>43.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>382.6\u00a0</td><td>0.33\u00a0</td><td>\u221239.9\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>159.0\u00a0</td><td>40.3\u00a0</td><td>281.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>233.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>33.9\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>44.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2SIS+\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>1.50\u00a0</td><td>363.4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>45.8\u00a0</td><td>225.9\u00a0</td><td>49.3\u00a0</td><td>263.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf7\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here <em>z</em> is the lens redshift, \u03c3 is the lens velocity dispersion, <em>e</em> and \u03b3 are the lens ellipticity and shear, respectively, and \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> and \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub> are their orientations (W of N). The time delays (last column) are in units of days.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515735\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515736 id=\"135515736\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Flux ratio analysis and the lens redshift</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We show the measured image flux ratios in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, based on Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. At least three of the six ratios show a clear dependence on wavelength. Interpreted as due to extinction, these ratios imply that A is the least reddened image, in agreement with image D being closest to the lensing galaxy, and the major axis of the lensing galaxy being oriented towards B and C (with B more reddened then C), according to the SIE+\u03b3 model. We also show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> the predicted flux ratios given by the SIS+\u03b3 model. The predicted SIE+\u03b3 fluxes are very similar, within <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }10{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, but the G+GX+\u03b3 model predicts a demagnified image A, about as bright as D. All models predict image B to be the brightest, as observed in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">VHS</a> data. The predicted B/C is invariant across all three models, as the shear is almost perpendicular to the direction of these two images. In fact, this ratio is the only one which matches the observations, in the reddest filter.</p>                        <a id=\"135515738\" scrollto-destination=\"135515738\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a06.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=bXNlZxDLyQDxUr0sf3o0VuU01P56TG2WsuU-tHWtauuERvBfvoslSyH0xuYcvjWxkDSZIgeIRV9xJSTlibter4QCUBzfF5XG1BSL8ookUIiVyqQj-4PPrOmYmpxvZtuvvUAlFUPCtCt3WUZBWrrM6Y7nYH0dKibRaZREf9SrgyCXjSxardA8mn2f7t0hSvDztAgndAMZ3KZ~kLNKOHh0BI3GR1FzYvynBVopRsXQNtU5~-DH2slmXnQe5DneTjpCPQWB~k5Vfa6dW0Y-wUAyWv9VZL15PKquzIgZ14b0SMTQPSi~Tl1WKc9GjrZTlKYb4xe2kGDyoiFwfstnQ-cXVw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured and model-predicted flux ratios of the four quasar images. Thick lines connect observed flux ratios in all available filters, and thin horizontal lines of corresponding colours mark the flux ratios predicted by the SIS+\u03b3 lens mass model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515738/stz1142fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515738\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=zgWWbcx0nTJNMq3nBx9ZDjGckLoemjd-BBWzMEazXTECWz0dx-k0nt4H4u1UlAZfYR2~xPXf-S9PqdkjvZAiV47LSn~ILDo5bila022jM58gKfz4XwRNzCU~74UaL7PATZZrpt3v3Tu35DRyOtvLyW1TM~0mh7YvE3WsI2NTLh49cbP~D0fTLGRkyPl8qVMXXCkhnuvBeqE25qaiqeKh3vwxMxA2rwEiVDCQUrAYRbBIlt-b2WZx-ip2tF7qbkYeCWuCw0C9BDUpsa025KbZ~2MDsylpyXFCVwSMg8I4WprpigF4NcWaAxkItxf4hyMPt6XoDDlx3hs-DRt65VOnKQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515738&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured and model-predicted flux ratios of the four quasar images. Thick lines connect observed flux ratios in all available filters, and thin horizontal lines of corresponding colours mark the flux ratios predicted by the SIS+\u03b3 lens mass model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a06.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=bXNlZxDLyQDxUr0sf3o0VuU01P56TG2WsuU-tHWtauuERvBfvoslSyH0xuYcvjWxkDSZIgeIRV9xJSTlibter4QCUBzfF5XG1BSL8ookUIiVyqQj-4PPrOmYmpxvZtuvvUAlFUPCtCt3WUZBWrrM6Y7nYH0dKibRaZREf9SrgyCXjSxardA8mn2f7t0hSvDztAgndAMZ3KZ~kLNKOHh0BI3GR1FzYvynBVopRsXQNtU5~-DH2slmXnQe5DneTjpCPQWB~k5Vfa6dW0Y-wUAyWv9VZL15PKquzIgZ14b0SMTQPSi~Tl1WKc9GjrZTlKYb4xe2kGDyoiFwfstnQ-cXVw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured and model-predicted flux ratios of the four quasar images. Thick lines connect observed flux ratios in all available filters, and thin horizontal lines of corresponding colours mark the flux ratios predicted by the SIS+\u03b3 lens mass model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515738/stz1142fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515738\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=zgWWbcx0nTJNMq3nBx9ZDjGckLoemjd-BBWzMEazXTECWz0dx-k0nt4H4u1UlAZfYR2~xPXf-S9PqdkjvZAiV47LSn~ILDo5bila022jM58gKfz4XwRNzCU~74UaL7PATZZrpt3v3Tu35DRyOtvLyW1TM~0mh7YvE3WsI2NTLh49cbP~D0fTLGRkyPl8qVMXXCkhnuvBeqE25qaiqeKh3vwxMxA2rwEiVDCQUrAYRbBIlt-b2WZx-ip2tF7qbkYeCWuCw0C9BDUpsa025KbZ~2MDsylpyXFCVwSMg8I4WprpigF4NcWaAxkItxf4hyMPt6XoDDlx3hs-DRt65VOnKQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515738&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured and model-predicted flux ratios of the four quasar images. Thick lines connect observed flux ratios in all available filters, and thin horizontal lines of corresponding colours mark the flux ratios predicted by the SIS+\u03b3 lens mass model.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Flux ratios of quasar images have been used in the past to study the extinction properties of lensing galaxies (e.g. Falco et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) as well as to infer lens redshifts (e.g. Jean\u00a0&amp; Surdej <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). Here, we use them to infer the lens redshift <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> as well as the de-reddened flux ratios (relative magnifications) <em>M<sub>i</sub></em>, where <em>i</em> refers to each of the six image pairs, independent of the chosen mass model. Following Falco et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), we optimize these parameters as well as the differential extinctions <em>E<sub>i</sub></em> and the shape of the extinction curve <em>R</em> by minimizing <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\chi ^2=\\sum _{j=1}^{N_\\lambda }\\sum _{i=1}^{N_\\mathrm{imag}}{\\frac{\\left[m^r_i(\\lambda _j)-m^b_i(\\lambda _j) - 2.5\\log M_i - E_iR\\left(\\frac{\\lambda _j}{1+z_l}\\right) \\right]^2}{\\sigma ^{b,2}_{ij}+\\sigma ^{r,2}_{ij}}} \\nonumber\\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>j</em> is the filter index, superscripts <em>b</em> and <em>r</em> refer to the blue and red images in each pair, respectively, and \u03c3<sub><em>ij</em></sub> is the magnitude measurement uncertainty. We use the central wavelength of each filter, and the Cardelli, Clayton\u00a0&amp; Mathis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) extinction function implemented in the code <span class=\"small-caps\">extinction</span>.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">10</a></sup> We perform the minimization using the Nelder\u2013Mead (Nelder\u00a0&amp; Mead <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1965</a>) method implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">scipy</span> (Oliphant <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), starting from random positions in the parameter space and further exploring around the solution with <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> (Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), to ensure that we have found the global solution.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find the best-fitting solution (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 213.4/16)<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn11\" data-open=\"fn11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">11</a></sup> with <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.45, <em>R</em> \u223c 2.5 slightly smaller than the Galactic extinction curve with <em>R<sub>V</sub></em>\u00a0= 3.1, small <em>E<sub>i</sub></em>\u00a0\u2272\u00a00.1 consistent with the results in Falco et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), and flux ratios B/A\u00a0=\u00a01.28, C/A\u00a0=\u00a01.20, D/A\u00a0=\u00a00.30. These parameter values are robust if we remove from the fit all image pairs containing D (new fit \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/d.o.f.\u00a0= 145.8/10), in case our decomposition of G and D is problematic due to the low image resolution. They are also robust to the choice of the extinction function. Except for B/C, which matches the prediction of the mass models, the flux ratios are smaller than predicted. The quality of the fits is statistically poor, although such large \u03c7<sup>2</sup> values are found by Falco et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) in other lensing systems as well. In our analysis, we have ignored any contribution from microlensing and quasar intrinsic variability, which can also affect flux ratios chromatically (e.g. Yonehara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We can look for signs of microlensing by plotting the quasar image spectral ratios. While the overall shape of these ratios is sensitive to observational effects such as suboptimal slit placement and differential refraction, these (as well as differential extinction) should affect both continua and emission lines equally. On the other hand, microlensing is dependent on the size of the source, such that the continuum emission, which originates from a more compact region than the broad emission lines, should be preferentially microlensed. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> clearly shows that, when dividing the fluxes of B and C to those of A<sub>BC</sub> (i.e. the A+D+G signal, dominated by A, and extracted from the BC slit) and of A<sub>AD</sub>, there is a large jump in the flux ratios at the locations of the SiV/OIV] (\u223c5270\u00c5) and CIV (\u223c5800\u00c5) broad-line regions, compared to the surrounding continuum. On the other hand, B/C is relatively flat over the entire plotted range, which means that microlensing affects image A+D (the saddle points of the time arrival surface) but not B and C. A direct comparison of the photometric flux ratios in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> with the spectroscopic ratios in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> is not possible due to the fact that the spectra are affected by slit losses. Indeed, this can be seen from the monotonic variation in A<sub>AD</sub>/A<sub>BC</sub>, which we attribute to the fact that ESI does not use an atmospheric dispersion corrector, thus resulting in flux losses from differential refraction, particularly between the orthogonally placed AD and BC slits. Also, the data sets are not concurrent, and are therefore prone to time-varying microlensing and intrinsic variability effects.</p>                        <a id=\"135515742\" scrollto-destination=\"135515742\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=kvQnKuT1DuS9b8vxSp1pN-DUHU6TQsRHN6D0XuXaV~g7e1CmEIjthlKq-DCjuccK2WljQN7iZc0xvnJ5Bs1YjM4epMWfq~ZiKw6ZxxHZIA5W8Kx-KN3UKgzrSvlBhqaVUP415onJTASwEseMkTZgZj4ZnJjrgVOgGWyIrYrATqWMX9AI7dfidA~vFMUHmZKCUOYLTn75QGtL7aG8sptnTRzV6jX1wxKleX1RbphtlUESuPV205WrnRo3GN9e53ri8Kk2TMByd-5UMWWgVU--vXY283syjdlgLno4DV-jomdZI2N3xfLZm0iyBQNEeOikuaLCjZzRFfgqs3RHQ0Tw8A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a06, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of AAD. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515742/stz1142fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515742\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=X8VSTOe2g7XAonhouecYPjmQFlfnn8o6BtxH7jljcfuHHzCEK5JxB6NkOCRzJHcF4-ffqgdOUiza2AIDxnhhd~eVfHrVQKtDCvxii2fOViQUVRapyZpZ5GDRD6b-~N5R0YyRUUGRPCFEYiWnlKmDoOm8lJryUMow3MFmCD9O~p9Olf1TQi7IgB68-3o7uxEn~L7sKD7jvUCUeE-wXs~m~EHB7DVHhAxTrr5N~VJdsxzYjjcN00Z~Zc9guqugI5VwcI4OtoWMWtINmUT7PFjvVU5L9OzsZqcInkdOIZW6eVllYXmhNAF2PcQnIySJD0~gQboYuaMOGnQwf~RHM05qVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515742&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of <em>A</em><sub>AD</sub>. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/m_stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&amp;Signature=kvQnKuT1DuS9b8vxSp1pN-DUHU6TQsRHN6D0XuXaV~g7e1CmEIjthlKq-DCjuccK2WljQN7iZc0xvnJ5Bs1YjM4epMWfq~ZiKw6ZxxHZIA5W8Kx-KN3UKgzrSvlBhqaVUP415onJTASwEseMkTZgZj4ZnJjrgVOgGWyIrYrATqWMX9AI7dfidA~vFMUHmZKCUOYLTn75QGtL7aG8sptnTRzV6jX1wxKleX1RbphtlUESuPV205WrnRo3GN9e53ri8Kk2TMByd-5UMWWgVU--vXY283syjdlgLno4DV-jomdZI2N3xfLZm0iyBQNEeOikuaLCjZzRFfgqs3RHQ0Tw8A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a06, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of AAD. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/135515742/stz1142fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"135515742\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/4/10.1093_mnras_stz1142/2/stz1142fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465041&Signature=X8VSTOe2g7XAonhouecYPjmQFlfnn8o6BtxH7jljcfuHHzCEK5JxB6NkOCRzJHcF4-ffqgdOUiza2AIDxnhhd~eVfHrVQKtDCvxii2fOViQUVRapyZpZ5GDRD6b-~N5R0YyRUUGRPCFEYiWnlKmDoOm8lJryUMow3MFmCD9O~p9Olf1TQi7IgB68-3o7uxEn~L7sKD7jvUCUeE-wXs~m~EHB7DVHhAxTrr5N~VJdsxzYjjcN00Z~Zc9guqugI5VwcI4OtoWMWtINmUT7PFjvVU5L9OzsZqcInkdOIZW6eVllYXmhNAF2PcQnIySJD0~gQboYuaMOGnQwf~RHM05qVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=135515742&ar=5484879&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1142fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured spectral flux ratios in the region 4830\u20139030 \u00c5, where the measurements are robust. The colours and line styles correspond to those in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, except that some flux ratios have been inverted and photometric ratios involving image D have been replaced with spectroscopic ratios of <em>A</em><sub>AD</sub>. The spikes correspond to the intrinsic or atmospheric absorption lines in the original spectra.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As discussed above, microlensing in particular may affect the inferred lens redshift. We note that due to the low image resolution, proximity to image D, and morphological compactness which may affect the extracted photometry, we could not obtain a robust photometric redshift for this galaxy. Looser but more robust redshift constraints can be set by using the observed image separation and the estimated magnitude of the lens in the filter in which it is brightest. On the one hand, the image separation gives the lens velocity dispersion as a function of redshift; on the other, assuming an early-type spectral template, the measured magnitude can be converted into a rest-frame absolute magnitude as a function of redshift,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn12\" data-open=\"fn12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">12</a></sup> and then into a velocity dispersion (Faber\u00a0&amp; Jackson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1976</a>). We find a lower limit of <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 0.5, below which the two velocity dispersion estimates disagree, and an upper limit of <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 1.5, above which the lens velocity dispersion is \u223c400\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, a value above which the galaxy velocity dispersion function is vanishingly small (Sheth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). The lower limit is close to the value inferred from our flux ratio analysis, and the upper one is consistent with the redshift of the narrow absorption systems identified in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>; it is also above the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L18</a> estimate of <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u223c 1.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515744 id=\"135515744\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have carried out a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">PS1</a>, based on visual examination of cut-outs around the AGN source catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and aided by astrometric quantities measured by <em>Gaia</em>. We present our sample of 91 promising candidates, not found in the available literature, in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, in order to enable follow-up observations by the interested community. We expect that the main source of contaminants are quasar pairs, which we see as a byproduct of our work, and to a lesser extent, quasar + star pairs. Our best estimate of the purity of our sample, in terms of lensed doubles and quasar pairs contaminated by quasar + star pairs, is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }70{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As part of our search, we have independently discovered six known quads, including 2M113\u22122103. We present, for the first time, spectroscopy of this system, confirming it as a lensed quasar with source redshift <em>z</em> \u223c 2.77. We identify absorption systems at <em>z</em> \u223c 1.5, in three of the resolved quasar images, but we find these to be too narrow to attribute to the lensing galaxy. The image flux ratios show a monotonic dependence on wavelength, which we use to obtain a rough estimate of the lens redshift, under the assumption that the dependence is caused by extinction. The spectral flux ratios show evidence of microlensing in the combined emission from images A and D.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our mass modelling confirms that 2M1134\u22122103 is affected by large shear, for which we identify two potential sources: a group of galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.7, 30\u2009arcsec from the lens, and another faint companion \u223c4\u2009arcsec away. Future multi-object spectroscopy is required to determine whether these are part of a larger cluster, or physically associated with the lens. The large image separation, brightness, and estimated time delays ranging from several days to several months, depending on the lens redshift, make this a valuable system to use for cosmography (e.g. Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), provided that the environment can be characterized with future, deep imaging and spectroscopy (e.g. Wilson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). High-resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> or adaptive optics imaging is necessary to constrain the morphology of the lensing galaxy, and to further constrain the mass models using the expected extended emission from the underlying host galaxy (e.g. Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515748 id=\"135515748\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors are indebted to the anonymous referee for thoroughly checking the sample of candidates, resulting in a significant improvement of our selection, and for suggesting the use of <em>Gaia</em>. We also wish to thank Paul L. Schechter for his \u2018matchmaking\u2019 which has made this paper possible. This research made use of <span class=\"small-caps\">astropy</span>, a community-developed core <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> package for Astronomy (Astropy Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Plots were produced with <span class=\"small-caps\">matplotlib</span> (Hunter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). This work was supported by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. CDF acknowledges support from the National Science Foundation under Grant No. AST-1715611.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys (<span class=\"xrefLink\" We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this superb mountain.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515755 id=\"135515755\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Lemon, Auger\u00a0&amp; McMahon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) have compiled an up-to-date list of known lensed quasars, maintained at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/</a>. Also, C. Lemon, private communication.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We use the version available on Vizier, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR\" target=\"_blank\">http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR</a>, which contains fewer contaminants</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Following step <em>iii</em>, we explored using an additional step to eliminate globular clusters and similar crowded regions, by imposing the condition that there are no more than seven counterparts within 10\u2009arcsec radius. This would have eliminated only 182 systems, all of which we have explored visually, making this step unnecessary.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label quasars survive our selection and grading process, but are not picked up by the cross-match with the catalogue of lenses because of differences in the reported coordinates: SDSS\u00a0J1320+1644 and SDSS\u00a0J1433+6007.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://hla.stsci.edu/fitscutcgi_interface.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://hla.stsci.edu/fitscutcgi_interface.html</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Our chosen limits recover almost all of our confirmed candidates: among our 25 spectroscopically confirmed lenses or quasar pairs, only 2, both quads with four detected components in <em>Gaia</em>, would be (partially) ruled out based on our <em>Gaia</em> classifier: PSJ0147+4630 has one component with large parallax, and PSJ1606\u22122333 has one with large proper motion.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn9\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn9\" class=\"end-note-link\">9</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Note that it is presently unknown whether SDSS\u00a0J1320+1644, counted here as a double, is in fact a double or a quasar pair (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal class=\"end-note-link\">10</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://extinction.readthedocs.io/en/latest/\" target=\"_blank\">http://extinction.readthedocs.io/en/latest/</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn11\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn11\" class=\"end-note-link\">11</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">With four images, thus three independent flux ratios in each band, and with eight bands, we have 24 constraints. As parameters, we have the redshift, the extinction curve parameter, three independent extinctions and 3 independent magnifications, thus eight parameters, resulting in 16 degrees of freedom.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn12\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn12\" class=\"end-note-link\">12</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">mag2mag</span> routine from Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/tcollett/LensPop/tree/master/stellarpop/\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/tcollett/LensPop/tree/master/stellarpop/</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn13\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn13\" class=\"end-note-link\">13</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.astro.rug.nl/\u00a0gaia/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.astro.rug.nl/\u00a0gaia/</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn14\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn14\" class=\"end-note-link\">14</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">From our 312 candidates, <em>G</em> \u2212 <em>g</em> has a distribution with a median of \u22120.21 and a standard deviation of 0.34</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=135515770 id=\"135515770\"
