class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib124\" data-legacy-id=\"bib124\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib124\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib124\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib124\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Yonehara</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Hirashita</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">H.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Richter</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2008</div>, <div class=\"source \">A&amp;A</div>, <div class=\"volume\">478</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">95</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361:20067014\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1051/0004-6361:20067014</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361:20067014\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1051%2F0004-6361:20067014\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1051%2F0004-6361:20067014\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib125\" data-legacy-id=\"bib125\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib125\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib125\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib125\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">York</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">D. G.</div></span> et al.\u00a0.</span>, <div class=\"year\">2000</div>, <div class=\"source \">AJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">120</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1579</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1086/301513\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1086/301513</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/301513\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1086%2F301513\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1086%2F301513\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515772 id=\"135515772\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX A: EXPECTED SAMPLE PURITY FROM THE RELATIVE DENSITY OF <em>GAIA</em> AND AGN SOURCES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We start with the complete <em>Gaia</em> DR2 source catalogue,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn13\" data-open=\"fn13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">13</a></sup> where we apply the same automatic selection cuts we used for our sample of candidates. We use a bright magnitude limit of <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2265\u00a017.5, slightly brighter than our candidate source companions, and a faint one of <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a020. While 29 of the 91 candidate source companions are fainter than <em>G</em>\u00a0= 20, we apply this cut because <em>Gaia</em> DR2 is still complete at this limit (Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), outside the crowded regions excluded by our galactic latitude cut; the completeness is expected to drop towards the limiting magnitude of <em>G</em> \u223c 21. This reduces the <em>Gaia</em> catalogue to \u223c148 million sources. We also apply a colour cut of 0\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<em>Rp</em> \u2212 <em>Bp</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a01.5, from Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, as well as the same <em>Gaia</em>-based astrometric quantity cuts from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>. As we did for our candidates, we keep the objects without <em>Gaia</em> astrometric quantities or colour. This results in \u223c22 million remaining sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) AGN catalogue is less complete, but not significantly so, with a limiting magnitude of 20 in <em>g</em> band, or about the same in <em>Gaia G</em> band.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn14\" data-open=\"fn14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">14</a></sup> We use the Milliquas catalogue (Flesch <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), which is slightly more complete at this magnitude limit (see fig.\u00a03 in Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), and includes high-confidence quasars detected in X-ray and radio, in addition to <em>WISE</em>. We cross-matched the <em>Gaia</em> catalogue after performing the cuts described above with the Milliquas catalogue, resulting in \u223c520\u2009000 matches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, the <em>Gaia</em> resolution is much higher than the one of <em>WISE</em>, with PSF FWHM \u223c6\u2009arcsec (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We use <span class=\"small-caps\">topcat</span> (Taylor <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) to identify all objects from the <em>Gaia</em>-based catalogue we produced above with relative separation less than the <em>WISE</em> PSF FWHM, and count each of these clusters as one. This reduces the <em>Gaia</em>-based sample to \u223c14 million sources, resulting in an AGN fraction of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }4{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=135515776 id=\"135515776\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX B: PREVIOUSLY CONFIRMED OR RULED OUT QSO+star (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>231209+203543\u00a0</td><td>348.036702\u00a0</td><td>20.595139\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>19.16\u00a0</td><td>3.1\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>p-l +extended; companion has large pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>231313+194722\u00a0</td><td>348.302961\u00a0</td><td>19.7895\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>17.63\u00a0</td><td>3.2\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>similar colour p-l; companion has large pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>231445+303530\u00a0</td><td>348.687176\u00a0</td><td>30.591695\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>17.20\u00a0</td><td>3.0\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>p-l; companion has large p and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>232837+435308\u00a0</td><td>352.152836\u00a0</td><td>43.885431\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>17.33\u00a0</td><td>2.1\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>p-l; companion has large pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>233611\u2212093523\u00a0</td><td>354.043989\u00a0</td><td>\u22129.589647\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>15.63\u00a0</td><td>4.1\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>similar colour p-l; companion has large p and pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>233700+180520\u00a0</td><td>354.249022\u00a0</td><td>18.088753\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>17.63\u00a0</td><td>3.7\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>p-l; companion has large pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>234155+132902\u00a0</td><td>355.480568\u00a0</td><td>13.483904\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>18.82\u00a0</td><td>3.2\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>similar colour p-l; includes SDSS <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.729 QSO; companion has large pm\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>235351\u2212053956\u00a0</td><td>358.462667\u00a0</td><td>\u22125.665505\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>16.5\u00a0</td><td>6.2\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>similar colour p-l (companion has large p and pm) +red inner component; QSO+star (Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf8\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf8\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The systems above the horizontal line are confirmed lenses or quasar pairs. The ones below are candidates ruled out either due to their <em>Gaia</em>-based properties, or due to spectroscopic results from the literature. The table structure is the same as in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. \u2018NIQ\u2019 stands for nearly identical quasars.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/135515777\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.486.4987R", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "We present results of a systematic search for gravitationally lensed quasars in Pan-STARRS1. Our final sample of candidates comprises of 91 systems, not including 25 rediscovered lensed quasars and quasar pairs. In the absence of spectroscopy to verify the lensing nature of the candidates, the main sources of contaminants are likely to be quasar pairs, which we consider to be a byproduct of our work, and a smaller number of quasar + star associations. Among the independently discovered quads is 2M1134-2103, for which we obtained spectroscopy for the first time, finding a redshift of 2.77 for the quasar. There is evidence for microlensing in at least one image. We perform detailed mass modelling of this system using archival imaging data, and find that the unusually large shear responsible for the diamond-like configuration can be attributed mainly to a faint companion \u223c4 arcsec away, and to a galaxy group/cluster \u223c30 arcsec away. We also set limits of z \u223c 0.5-1.5 on the redshift of the lensing galaxy, based on its brightness, the image separation of the lensed images, and an analysis of the observed photometric flux ratios.", "start_page": "4987", "authors": ["Rusu, Cristian E.", "Berghea, Ciprian T.", "Fassnacht, Christopher D.", "More, Anupreeta", "Seman, Erica", "Nelson, George J.", "Chen, Geoff C. -F."], "issn": "0035-8711", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1803.07175", "Title": "A search for gravitationally lensed quasars and quasar pairs in Pan-STARRS1: spectroscopy and sources of shear in the diamond 2M1134-2103", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "quasars: individual: 2M1134-2103", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "volume": "486", "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.486.4987R", "end_page": "5007", "number": "4", "publication_year": "2019/07/1", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stz1142", "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "author_address": ["AA(Subaru Telescope, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan, 650 N Aohoku Pl, Hilo, HI 96720, USA;), AB(U.S. Naval Observatory (USNO), 3450 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20392, USA), AC(Department of Physics, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, USA), AD(Kavli IPMU (WPI), UTIAS, The University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8583, Japan; Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics, Post Bag 4, Ganeshkhind, Pune 410007, India), AE(U.S. Naval Observatory (USNO), 3450 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20392, USA), AF(U.S. Naval Observatory (USNO), 3450 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20392, USA), AG(Department of Physics, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, USA)"]}, "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Status": "Complete", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2019MNRAS.486.4987R/PUB_HTML"}
